member.name: P:Au.Acc.KeyboardShortcut
member.summary: Gets keyboard shortcut. Uses IAccessible.get_accKeyboardShortcut.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Acc.DefaultAction
member.summary: Gets default action. Uses IAccessible.get_accDefaultAction.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this property is unavailable or if failed. Supports . If this is a Java accessible object, returns all actions that can be used with , like "action1, action2, action3", from which the first is considered default and is used by .

member.name: M:Au.Acc.DoAction
member.summary: Performs the object's default action (see ). Usually it is 'click', 'press' or similar. Uses IAccessible.accDoDefaultAction.
member.remarks: Fails if the object does not have a default action. Then you can use , or try , , and keyboard functions. The action can take long time, for example show a dialog. This function normally does not wait. It allows the caller to automate the dialog. If it waits, try or one of the above functions (MouseClick etc).

member.name: M:Au.Acc.VirtualClick
member.summary: Posts mouse-left-click message to the container window, using coordinates of this object.
member.exception: Failed to get rectangle, or the object is invisible/offscreen.
member.remarks: Does not move the mouse. Does not wait until the target application finishes processing the message. Works not with all objects. Use (try) this function when the object does not support . When both don't work, use MouseClick.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.VirtualRightClick
member.summary: Posts mouse-right-click message to the container window, using coordinates of this object.
member.exception: Failed to get rectangle, or the object is invisible/offscreen.
member.remarks: Does not move the mouse. Does not wait until the target application finishes processing the message. Works not with all objects. When does not work, use MouseClick.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.DoJavaAction(System.String)
member.summary: Performs one of actions supported by this Java accessible object.
member.param: Action name. See . If null (default), performs default action (like ) or posts Space key message. More info in Remarks.
member.remarks:
Read more about Java accessible objects in topic.
Problem: if the action opens a dialog, DoAction/DoJavaAction do not return until the dialog is closed (or fail after some time). The caller then waits and cannot automate the dialog. Also then this process cannot exit until the dialog is closed. If the action parameter is null and the object is focusable, this function tries a workaround: it makes the object (button etc) focused and posts Space key message, which should press the button; then this function does not wait.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.DoActionAndWaitForNewWebPage(System.Double,System.Action{Au.Acc})
member.summary: Calls or and waits until window name changes and web page name changes.
member.param: Default 60 seconds.
If used, calls it instead of .
member.exception: Failed. For example, when this object is invalid, or its top-level window does not contain a web page.
The window was closed while waiting.
Exceptions thrown by or by the function.
member.remarks: This function is used to click a link in a web page and wait until current web page is gone. It prevents a following 'wait for object' function from finding a matching object in the old page, which would be bad. This function does not wait until the new page is completely loaded. There is no reliable/universal way for it. Instead, after calling it you can call a 'wait for object' function which waits for a known object that must be in the new page. This function cannot be used when the new page has the same title as current page. Then it waits until time or forever. The same if the action does not open a web page.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.Select(Au.Types.AccSELFLAG)
member.summary: Selects or deselects.
member.param: Specifies whether to select, focus, add to selection etc. Can be two flags, for example AccSELFLAG.TAKEFOCUS | AccSELFLAG.TAKESELECTION.
member.exception: Failed to activate the window () or focus the control ().
member.remarks: Uses IAccessible.accSelect. Not all objects support it. Most objects support not all flags. It depends on object states FOCUSABLE, SELECTABLE, MULTISELECTABLE, EXTSELECTABLE, DISABLED. Many object have bugs, especially with flag TAKEFOCUS. More bugs when the object found with flag .

member.name: M:Au.Acc.Focus(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Makes this object focused for keyboard input.
member.param: Add flag TAKESELECTION. Note: it is for selecting a list item, not for selecting text in a text box.
member.remarks: Calls with flag TAKEFOCUS and optionally TAKESELECTION. Not all objects support this action and not all work correctly. More info in Select documentation.

member.name: P:Au.Acc.SelectedChildren
member.summary: Gets selected direct child items. Returns empty array if there are no selected items of if failed. Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Acc.ChildCount
member.summary: Gets the number of direct child objects. Uses IAccessible.get_accChildCount.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.GetProperties(System.String,Au.Types.AccProperties@)
member.summary: Gets multiple properties.
member.param: Which properties to get. Each character specifies a property: 'R' - . 'n' - . 'v' - . 'd' - . 'h' - . 'a' - . 'k' - . 'u' - . 's' - . 'r' - . 'w' - . 'o' - outer. 'i' - inner. '@' - .
Receives results.
member.remarks:
The returned variable contains values of properties specified in . When a property is empty or failed to get, the member variable is "", empty dictionary or default value of that type; never null.
Normally this function is faster than calling multiple property functions, because it makes single remote procedure call. But not if this accessible object was found with flag etc.
Returns false if fails, for example when the object's window is closed. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Acc.Navigate(System.String,System.Double)
member.summary: Gets an adjacent or related accessible object (AO) - next, child, parent, etc. Returns null if not found.
member.param:
String consisting of one or more navigation direction strings separated by space, like "parent next child4 first".
"next" - next sibling AO in the same parent AO.
"previous" - previous sibling AO in the same parent AO.
"first" - first child AO.
"last" - last child AO.
"parent" - parent (container) AO.
"child" - child AO by 1-based index. Example: "child3" (3-th child). Negative index means from end, for example -1 is the last child.
"#N" - N is a numeric value to pass to IAccessible.accNavigate as navDir. Can be any standard or custom value supported by the AO.
Can be only 2 letters, like "pr" for "previous". A string like "next3" or "next,3" is the same as "next next next". Except for "child".
For "next", "previous", "firstchild", "lastchild", "#N" is used IAccessible.accNavigate. Not all AOs support it. Some AOs skip invisible siblings. Instead you can use "parent childN" or "childN". For "parent" is used IAccessible.get_accParent. Few AOs don't support. Some AOs return a different parent than in the AO tree. For "child" is used API AccessibleChildren.
Wait for the wanted AO max this number of seconds. If negative, waits forever.

example.code: a = a.Navigate("parent next ch3", true);

member.name: M:Au.Acc.Html(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets HTML.
member.param: If true, gets outer HTML (with tag and attributes), else inner HTML.
member.remarks: Returns "" if this is not a HTML element or if failed. Supports . Works with Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer and apps that use their code (Thunderbird, Opera, web browser controls...). This object must be found without flag NotInProc. If this is the root of web page (role DOCUMENT or PANE), gets web page body HTML.

member.remarks: Returns "" if this is not a HTML element or does not have the specified attribute or failed. Supports . Works with Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer and apps that use their code (Thunderbird, Opera, web browser controls...). This object must be found without flag NotInProc.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.HtmlAttributes
member.summary: Gets all HTML attributes.
member.remarks: Returns empty dictionary if this is not a HTML element or does not have attributes or failed. Supports . Works with Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer and apps that use their code (Thunderbird, Opera, web browser controls...). This object must be found without flag NotInProc.

This function works with these objects:
Web page objects in Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer and apps that use their code (Thunderbird, Opera, web browser controls...). With Find use role prefix "web:", "firefox:" or "chrome:", and don't use flag .
Objects in Edge browser, standard treeview and listview controls, some other. With Find use flag .

Control properties. This functions searches in all matching controls.
member.remarks: Alternatively you can specify control class name or id in role. How this function is different: 1. Allows to specify more control properties. 2. Works better/faster when the control is of a different process or thread than the parent window; else slightly slower.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.Find(Au.Wnd,System.String,System.String,System.String,Au.Types.AFFlags,System.Func{Au.Acc,System.Boolean},System.Int32,System.String,Au.Wnd.ChildFinder)
member.summary: Finds accessible object (AO) in window. Returns the found AO. Returns null if not found. See examples.
member.param: Window or control that contains the AO.

AO role, like "LINK". Or path, like "ROLE/ROLE/ROLE". See . Can be used standard roles (see ) and custom roles (like "div" in Firefox). This parameter is string. If you want to use : nameof(AccROLE.CHECKBOX). Case-sensitive, not wildcard. Use null to match any role. Cannot be "".
Role or path can have a prefix:
"web:" - search only in the visible web page, not in whole window. Examples: "web:LINK", "web:/LIST/LISTITEM/LINK". Supports Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer (IE) and apps that use their code. With other windows, searches in the first found visible AO that has DOCUMENT role. Chrome web page accessible objects normally are disabled (don't exist). Use prefix "web:" or "chrome:" to enable. Tip: To search only NOT in web pages, use "notin=DOCUMENT" (Chrome, Firefox) or "notin=PANE" (IE).
"firefox:" - search only in the visible web page of Firefox or Firefox-based web browser. If w window class name starts with "Mozilla", can be used "web:" instead.
"chrome:" - search only in the visible web page of Chrome or Chrome-based web browser. If w window class name starts with "Chrome", can be used "web:" instead.
Prefix cannot be used if: contains "id" or "class"; with flag ; searching in Acc ().
Can be used path consisting of roles separated by "/". Examples:
"web:DOCUMENT/div/LIST/LISTITEM/LINK" - find LINK using its full path in web page.
"web:/div/LIST//LINK" - the empty parts mean 'any role'. For example don't need to specify DOCUMENT because in web pages the first part is always DOCUMENT (Firefox, Chrome) or PANE (IE).
"web:/div/LIST[4]/LISTITEM[-1]/LINK" - the 4 is 1-based index of div child from which to start searching (4-th, then 3-th, 5-th and so on). It can make faster. Negative means 'index from end', for example use -1 to search in reverse order. Flag is not applied to path parts with indexes. If index is invalid, will use the nearest valid index.
"web:/div/LIST[4!]/LISTITEM[-1!]/LINK" - like the above, but the LIST must be exactly 4-th child (don't search 3-th, 5-th etc) and the LISTITEM must be the last child. This can be useful when waiting (uses less CPU), however useless if AO indices in the window or web page change often.
"web://[4]/[-1!]/[2]" - index without role.
"CLIENT/WINDOW/TREE/TREEITEM[-1]" - path in window or control. The first path part is a direct child AO of the WINDOW AO of the window/control. The WINDOW AO itself is not included in the search; if you need it, instead use .
AO name (). String format: wildcard expression. null means 'any'. "" means 'empty or unavailable'.

Other AO properties and search settings. Format: one or more "name=value", separated with "\0" or "\0 ", like "description=xxx\0 @href=yyy". Names must match case. Values of string properties are wildcard expressions.
"class" - search only in child controls that have this class name (see ). Cannot be used when searching in Acc.
"id" - search only in child controls that have this id (see ). Cannot be used when searching in Acc.
"value" - .
"description" - .
"state" - . List of states that the AO must have and/or not have. Example: "state=CHECKED, FOCUSABLE, !DISABLED". Example: "state=0x100010, !0x1". Will find AO that has all states without "!" prefix and does not have any of states with "!" prefix.
"rect" - . Can be specified left, top, width and/or height, using format. Example: "rect={L=1155 T=1182 W=132 H=13}". Example: "rect={W=132 T=1182}". The L T coordinates are relative to the primary screen.
"level" - level (see ) at which the AO can be found. Can be exact level, or minimal and maximal level separated by space. The default value is 0 1000. Alternatively you can use path in role, like "////LINK".
"elem" - .
"action" - .
"key" - .
"help" - .
"uiaid" - .
"maxcc" - when searching, skip children of AO that have more than this number of direct children. It can make faster. The default value is 10000. It also prevents hanging or crashing when an AO in the object tree has large number of children. For example OpenOffice Calc TABLE has one billion children.
"notin" - when searching, skip children of AO that have these roles. It can make faster. Example: "notin=TREE,LIST,TOOLBAR". Roles in the list must be separated with "," or ", ". Case-sensitive, not wildcard. See also: .
"@attr" - . Here "attr" is any attribute name. Example: "@id=example".
Callback function. Called for each matching AO. Let it return true if this is the wanted AO. Example, the AO must contain point x y: o => o.GetRect(out var r, o.WndTopLevel) && r.Contains(266, 33)
0-based index of matching AO. For example, if 1, the function skips the first matching AO and returns the second.
If not null, call with this string and return its result.

Properties of child controls where to search. This is an alternative for class/id in . Allows to specify more control properties. Works better/faster when the control is of a different process or thread than the parent window; else slightly slower.
member.exception: is "" or invalid. is invalid wildcard expression ("**options " or regular expression). has invalid format or contains unknown property names or invalid wildcard expressions. string is invalid. Using flag when searching in web page (role prefix "web:" etc).
Invalid window (if the function has parameter ).
Failed. For example, window of a higher UAC integrity level process.
member.remarks:
To create code for this function, use dialog "Find accessible object". It is form Au.Tools.Form_Acc in Au.Tools.dll.
Walks the tree of accessible objects, until finds a matching AO. Uses . You can use it directly. See example. In wildcard expressions supports PCRE regular expressions (prefix "**r ") but not .NET regular expressions (prefix "**R "). They are similar. To find web page AOs usually it's better to use instead, it's more reliable. More info in topic.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.Find(System.String,System.String,System.String,Au.Types.AFFlags,System.Func{Au.Acc,System.Boolean},System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Finds a descendant accessible object (AO) of this AO. Returns the found AO. Returns null if not found.
member.exception: is "" or invalid or has a prefix ("web:" etc). is invalid wildcard expression ("**options " or regular expression). has invalid format or contains unknown property names or invalid wildcard expressions or "class", "id". string is invalid. Using flag . is not 0.

member.name: M:Au.Acc.Wait(System.Double,Au.Wnd,System.String,System.String,System.String,Au.Types.AFFlags,System.Func{Au.Acc,System.Boolean},System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Finds accessible object (AO) in window. Waits until the AO is found or the given time expires.
member.param: The maximal time to wait, seconds. If 0, waits infinitely. If >0, after that time interval throws . If <0, after that time interval returns null.
member.returns: Returns the found AO. On timeout returns null if is negative; else exception.

member.summary: Gets or changes simple element id, also known as child id.
member.remarks: Most accessible objects (AO) are not simple elements. Then this property is 0. Often (but not always) this property is the 1-based item index in parent AO. For example LISTITEM in LIST. The 'set' function sometimes can be used as a fast alternative to . It modifies only this variable. It does not check whether the value is valid. Simple elements cannot have child AOs.

member.name: P:Au.Acc.Level
member.summary: Gets or sets indentation level for .
member.remarks: When Find or similar function finds an accessible object, it sets this property of the Acc variable. When searching in a window or control, at level 0 are direct children of the WINDOW object of the window or control. When searching in Acc, at level 0 are direct children of the Acc. When searching in web page (role prefix "web:" etc), at level 0 is the web page object (role DOCUMENT or PANE).

member.name: M:Au.Acc.FromEvent(Au.Wnd,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the accessible object that generated the event that is currently being processed by the callback function used with API SetWinEventHook or . Returns null if failed. Suports .
member.remarks: The parameters are of the callback function. Uses API AccessibleObjectFromEvent. Often fails because the object already does not exist, because the callback function is called asynchronously, especially when the event is OBJECT_DESTROY, OBJECT_HIDE, SYSTEM_*END. Returns null if failed. Always check the return value, to avoid NullReferenceException. An exception in the callback function kills this process.

member.remarks: Uses . Catches exceptions. On exception prints $"!exception! exceptionType exceptionMessage". Parameters are of . By default skips invisible objects and objects in menus. Use flags to include them. Chrome web page accessible objects normally are disabled (missing) when it starts. Use role prefix "web:" or "chrome:" to enable. See example.

member.name: T:Au.Util.IconsAsync
member.summary: Gets file icons asynchronously.
member.remarks: Use to avoid waiting until all icons are extracted before displaying them in a UI (menu etc). Instead you show the UI without icons, and then asynchronously receive icons when they are extracted. At first call (for each file) or . Then call . Create a callback function of type and pass its delegate to GetAllAsync.

member.summary: Adds a file path to an internal collection.
member.param: File path etc. See .
Something to pass to your callback function together with icon handle for this file.

member.summary: Adds multiple file paths to an internal collection. The same as calling multiple times. This function copies the list.

member.name: P:Au.Util.IconsAsync.Count
member.summary: Gets the number of added items. sets it = 0.

member.name: M:Au.Util.IconsAsync.GetAllAsync(Au.Util.IconsAsync.Callback,System.Int32,Au.Types.GIFlags,System.Object)
member.summary: Starts getting icons of added files.
member.param: A callback function delegate.
Icon width and height. Also can be enum , cast to int.
Something to pass to callback functions.
member.remarks: After this function returns, icons are asynchronously extracted with , and callback called with icon handle (or default(IntPtr) if failed). The callback is called in this thread. This thread must have a message loop (eg Application.Run). If you'll need more icons, you can add more files and call this function again with the same IconsAsync instance, even if getting old icons if still not finished.

member.name: T:Au.Util.OutputServer
member.summary: Receives messages sent by and related methods (Print etc).
member.remarks:
If server is global, clients can be multiple appdomains and processes, including this. Else only this appdomain. Works asynchronously, to make writing messages faster. When a client writes a message, the message arrives to the server with some delay and is placed in a queue. You then can get/remove messages from the queue (call ) and display them in a window (for example). You can be notified about new messages.
Recommended setup (see example): 1. When your application starts, create an OutputServer instance and assign to a static variable. Call . 2. When your application creates its output window, call to register callback function. 3. In the callback function get/remove/display all new messages. 4. Call when closing the window. Optional but recommended.

member.name: T:Au.Util.LibArrayBuilder`1
member.summary: Like List or StringBuilder, used as a temporary variable-size array to create final fixed-size array. To avoid much garbage (and many reallocations when growing), uses native memory heap. See . Must be explicitly disposed to free the native memory. Set all added bytes = 0. If false, the added memory is uninitialized, ie random byte values. Default true. Slower when true.

member.name: T:Au.Util.StringCache
member.summary: Caches managed strings created from unmanaged char* buffers.
member.remarks: Can be used in possibly very frequently called functions to avoid much string garbage and frequent garbage collections. For example, Wnd.ClassName and Wnd.Name use this. They are called by Wnd.Wait for each window (can be hundreds of them) repeatedly. It could create megabytes of garbage (window classname and name strings) in a few seconds. Every loop creates almost the same set of strings, therefore it makes sense to cache them. To allow GC free the cached strings, use a WeakReferenc<StringCache> object. See example.

member.name: P:Au.Util.StringCache.Count
member.summary: Number of elements in this cache.

member.name: M:Au.Util.StringCache.Add(System.Char*,System.Int32)
member.summary: Searches in the cache for a managed string that matches unmanaged string p of length len. If finds, returns it. Else adds new string(p, 0, len) to the cache and returns it.
member.param: Unmanaged string.
p length.
member.remarks: speed when found in cache: similar to new string(p, 0, len).

p length.
Call len = LibCharPtr.Length(p, len).

member.name: T:Au.Util.LibProcessMemory
member.summary: Memory shared by all appdomains of current process. Size 0x10000 (64 KB). Initially zero.
member.remarks: When need to prevent simultaneous access of the memory by multiple threads, use lock("uniqueString"){...} . It locks in all appdomains, because literal strings are interned, ie shared by all appdomains. Using some other object with 'lock' would lock only in that appdomain. Maybe except Type. Use this only in single module, because ngened modules have own interned strings.

member.name: T:Au.Util.NativeHeap
member.summary: Allocates memory from native heap of this process using heap API. Uses the common heap of this process, API GetProcessHeap. Usually slightly faster than Marshal class functions.

member.name: M:Au.Util.NativeHeap.Alloc(Au.Types.LPARAM,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Allocates new memory block and returns its address. Calls API HeapAlloc.
member.param: Byte count.
Set all bytes = 0. If false (default), the memory is uninitialized, ie random byte values. Slower when true.
member.exception: Failed. Probably size is too big.
member.remarks: The memory is unmanaged and will not be freed automatically. Always call when done or if need to resize it without losing data.

member.name: M:Au.Util.NativeHeap.ReAlloc(System.Void*,Au.Types.LPARAM,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Reallocates a memory block to make it bigger or smaller. Returns its address, which in most cases is different than the old memory block address. Preserves data in Math.Min(old size, new size) bytes of old memory (copies from old memory if need). Calls API HeapReAlloc or HeapAlloc.
member.param: Old memory address. If null, allocates new memory like Alloc.
New byte count.
When size is growing, set all added bytes = 0. If false (default), the added memory is uninitialized, ie random byte values. Slower when true.
member.exception: Failed. Probably size is too big.
member.remarks: The memory is unmanaged and will not be freed automatically. Always call when done or ReAlloc if need to resize it without losing data.

member.name: M:Au.Util.NativeHeap.Free(System.Void*)
member.summary: Frees a memory block. Does nothing if mem is null. Calls API HeapFree.

member.name: T:Au.Util.Buffers
member.summary: Allocates memory buffers that can be used with API functions and not only. Can allocate arrays of any value type - char[], byte[] etc.

member.name: M:Au.Util.Buffers.Get``1(System.Int32,System.WeakReference{``0[]}@)
member.summary: Allocates new or gets "cached" array of type T of length n or more. The returned array is managed by a WeakReference<T[]> variable provided by the caller. Its contents is undefined.
member.typeparam: Any value type, for example char, byte, RECT.
member.param: How many elements you need. If array in the WeakReference variable is null or too small, creates new array and stores it there. For byte[] and char[] types actually allocates Math.Max(n, 300)+1 elements. The 300 is to avoid future reallocations. The +1 can be used for example for '\0' character at the end of string.

A reference to a WeakReference variable that manages the returned array. If null, this function will create it. The variable should be [ThreadStatic] static. Or can be a non-static field of a long-living object. Must not be simply static, it's not thread-safe (unless locked).
member.remarks: Used to avoid creating much garbage when array allocations are needed frequently. Also is faster than code like var b=new byte[1000] or StringBuilder. The WeakReference variable allows the array to be garbage-collected if it is not used when GC runs. It is automatic and safe. Next time this function will create new array. Actually this function is a wrapper for WeakReference<T[]> functions TryGetTarget/SetTarget. Makes it easier to use.

member.name: T:Au.Util.LibStringBuilder
member.summary: Provides a cached reusable instance of StringBuilder per thread. It's an optimisation that reduces the number of instances constructed and collected. Used like using(new Au.Util.LibStringBuilder(out var b)) { b.Append("example"); var s = b.ToString(); }.
member.remarks: This is a modified copy of the .NET internal StringBuilderCache class. The cache uses 2 [ThreadLocal] StringBuilder instances, which allows 1 nesting level. Not error to use deeper nesting level, but then gets new StringBuilder, not from the cache.

For example it can set completionCallback = null to prevent calling it (the call is expensive); or change state, if want to pass another object to the completion function. Note that the completion function is never called if initially it was null.

Callback function to call in a thread pool thread.

member.summary: Creates a object that can be used when need more options than has.

Callback function to call in a thread pool thread.
Optional callback function to call in this thread after workCallback.
member.remarks: Call Dispose() to avoid memory leaks. If not called, the object and related OS object remain in memory until this appdomain ends.
member.exception: (only when completionCallback is used) This thread has a synchronization context other than WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext or null; or it is null and thread's GetApartmentState is not STA.

member.summary: Allows to submit a callback function (one or more times) to be called in thread pool threads, then optionally wait and cancel. Can be used when need more options than has.

member.summary: Requests that a thread pool thread call the callback function. This function can be called multiple times.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.Work.Wait
member.summary: Waits until all submitted instances of the callback function finish their work. While waiting, this thread cannot dispatch events and Windows messages.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.Work.Cancel
member.summary: Waits until all running instances of the callback function finish their work, and cancels pending (still not running) instances. While waiting, this thread cannot dispatch events and Windows messages.

member.name: M:Au.Util.ThreadPoolSTA.Work.Dispose
member.summary: Calls , releases all resources used by this object and allows this object to be garbage-collected. Call this to avoid memory leaks. If not called, the object and related OS object remain in memory until this appdomain ends.

member.name: T:Au.BlockUserInput
member.summary: Blocks keyboard and/or mouse input events from reaching applications.
member.remarks:
Uses keyboard and/or mouse hooks. Does not use API BlockInput, it does not work on current Windows versions. Blocks hardware-generated events and software-generated events, except if generated by functions of this library. Functions of this library that send keys or text use this class internally, to block user-pressed keys and resend them afterwards (see ). Does not block:
In windows of the same thread that started blocking. For example, if your script shows a message box, the user can click its buttons.
In windows of higher UAC integrity level (IL) processes, unless this process has uiAccess IL.
In special screens such as when you press Ctrl+Alt+Delete or when you launch and admin program. See also .
Some Windows hotkeys, such as Ctrl+Alt+Delete and Win+L.
keys.
Keyboard hooks don't work in windows of this process if this process uses direct input or raw input API.
To stop blocking, can be used the 'using' pattern, like in the example. Or the 'try/finally' pattern, where the finally block calls or . Also automatically stops when this thread ends. Users can stop with Ctrl+Alt+Delete.

member.name: M:Au.BlockUserInput.#ctor
member.summary: This constructor does nothing (does not call ).

member.name: M:Au.BlockUserInput.#ctor(Au.Types.BIEvents)
member.summary: This constructor calls .

member.name: M:Au.BlockUserInput.Start(Au.Types.BIEvents)
member.summary: Starts blocking.

member.name: M:Au.BlockUserInput.Dispose
member.summary: Calls .

member.name: M:Au.BlockUserInput.Stop(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Stops blocking. Plays back blocked keys if need. See . Does nothing if currently is not blocking.
member.param: Do not play back blocked keys recorded because of .

member.name: P:Au.BlockUserInput.ResumeAfterCtrlAltDelete
member.summary: Continue blocking when returned from a special screen where blocking is disabled: Ctrl+Alt+Delete, UAC consent, etc.

member.name: P:Au.BlockUserInput.ResendBlockedKeys
member.summary: Record blocked keys, and play back when stopped blocking.
member.remarks: Will not play back if: 1. The blocking time is >= 10 seconds. 2. Detected Ctrl+Alt+Delete, UAC consent or some other special screen. 3. Called .

member.name: P:Au.BlockUserInput.DoNotBlockInjectedExtraInfo
member.summary: Do not block software-generated key/mouse events if this extra info value was set when calling API SendInput. The default value is the value used by functions of this library, that is why their events are not blocked. If changed, their events are blocked, unless is true.

member.name: P:Au.BlockUserInput.DoNotBlockInjected
member.summary: Do not block software-generated key/mouse events. If false (default), only events generated by functions of this library are not blocked, unless is changed.

member.name: P:Au.BlockUserInput.DoNotBlockKeys
member.summary: Do not block these keys. Default: { KKey.Pause, KKey.PrintScreen, KKey.F1 }.
member.remarks: The array should contain keys without modifier key flags.

member.name: P:Au.BlockUserInput.Pause
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the blocking is paused.
member.remarks: The 'set' function is much faster than /. Does not remove hooks etc. Discards blocked keys.

member.name: T:Au.Clipb
member.summary: Clipboard functions: copy, paste, get and set clipboard text and other data.
member.remarks:
This class is similar to the .NET class, which uses OLE API, works only in STA threads and does not work well in automation scripts. This class uses non-OLE API and works well in automation scripts and any threads.
To set/get clipboard data of non-text formats, use class ; to paste, use it with ; to copy (get from the active app), use it with .
Should not be used to copy/paste in windows of own thread. In most cases it works, but strange problems are possible, because it waits until the window processes the copy/paste request, and while waiting it gets/dispatches all messages/events/etc. It's better to call it from another thread. Example in .

member.name: M:Au.Clipb.Clear
member.summary: Clears the clipboard.
member.exception: Failed to open clipboard (after 10 s of wait/retry).

member.name: P:Au.Clipb.Text
member.summary: Gets or sets clipboard text.
member.exception: Failed to open clipboard (after 10 s of wait/retry) or set clipboard data.
The 'set' function failed to allocate memory.
member.remarks: The 'get' function calls . Also can get file paths, as multiline text. Returns null if there is no text/files.

member.name: M:Au.Clipb._SetClipboardData_ClipboardViewerIgnore
member.summary: Calls API SetClipboardData("Clipboard Viewer Ignore"). Clipboard must be open. Then clipboard manager/viewer/etc programs that are aware of this convention don't try to get our clipboard data while we are pasting. Tested apps that support it: Ditto, Clipdiary. Other 5 tested apps don't.

member.name: M:Au.Clipb.CopyText(System.Boolean,Au.Types.OptKey)
member.summary: Gets the selected text from the focused app using the clipboard.
member.param: Use Ctrl+X.
Options. If null (default), uses . Uses , , . Does not use .
member.remarks: Also can get file paths, as multiline text. Sends keys Ctrl+C, waits until the focused app sets clipboard data, gets it, finally restores clipboard data. Fails (exception) if the focused app does not set clipboard text or file paths, for example if there is no selected text/files. Works with console windows too, even if they don't support Ctrl+C.

member.name: M:Au.Clipb.CopyData(System.Action,System.Boolean,Au.Types.OptKey)
member.summary: Gets data of any formats from the focused app using the clipboard and a callback function.
member.param: Callback function. It can get clipboard data of any formats. It can use any clipboard functions, for example the class or the .NET class. Don't call copy/paste functions.
Use Ctrl+X.
member.exception: Exceptions thrown by the callback function.
member.remarks: Sends keys Ctrl+C, waits until the focused app sets clipboard data, calls callback function that gets it, finally restores clipboard data. Fails (exception) if the focused app does not set clipboard data. Works with console windows too, even if they don't support Ctrl+C.

member.name: M:Au.Clipb.PasteText(System.String,Au.Types.OptKey)
member.summary: Pastes text into the focused app using the clipboard.
member.param: Text.
Options. If null (default), uses . Uses , , , , , .
member.remarks: Adds to the clipboard, sends keys Ctrl+V, waits until the focused app gets clipboard data, finally restores clipboard data. Fails (exception) if nothing gets clipboard data in several seconds. Works with console windows too, even if they don't support Ctrl+V. A clipboard viewer/manager program can make this function slower and less reliable, unless it supports or gets clipboard data with a delay. Possible problems with some virtual PC programs. Either pasting does not work in their windows, or they use a hidden clipboard viewer that makes this function slower and less reliable.

example.code: Clipb.PasteText("Example\r\n"); Paste("Example\r\n"); //the same as above

member.name: M:Au.Clipb.PasteData(Au.Clipb.Data,Au.Types.OptKey)
member.summary: Pastes data added to a variable into the focused app using the clipboard.
member.example: Paste data of two formats: HTML and text. Clipb.PasteData(new Clipb.Data().AddHtml("text").AddText("text"));

member.param: string or Data.

member.name: T:Au.Keyb
member.summary: Keyboard functions: send virtual keystrokes and text to the active window, get key states.
member.remarks: The main function is . Most documentation is there. See also . These functions use . Alternatively can be used Keyb variables, see .

example.code:
Keyb.Key("Ctrl+Shift+Left"); //press Ctrl+Shift+Left
Opt.Key.KeySpeed = 300; //set options for static functions Keyb.Key("Ctrl+A Del Tab*3", "text", "Enter", 500); //press Ctrl+A, press Del, press Tab 3 times, send text, press Enter, wait 100 ms
Keyb.Text("text\r\n"); //send text that ends with newline Keyb.Text("text", "Enter", 300); //send text, press Enter, wait 300 ms
Text("Key and Text can be used without the \"Keyb.\" prefix."); Key("Enter");

Scan code of the physical key. Scan code values are 1-127, but this function allows 1-0xffff. Can be 0.
true if the key is an extended key.
true - key down; false - key up; null (default) - key down-up.

member.name: M:Au.Keyb.GetKeyState(Au.Types.KKey)
member.summary: Calls API GetKeyState and returns its return value.
member.remarks: If returns < 0, the key is pressed. If the low-order bit is 1, the key is toggled; not all keys can be toggled. This key state changes when the active app receives the key down or up notification. This and other 'get key state' functions of this library except use API GetKeyState. If a key is blocked by a hook, its state does not change. If it's a low-level hook, then it's impossible to detect whether the key is physically pressed.

member.name: M:Au.Keyb.GetAsyncKeyState(Au.Types.KKey)
member.summary: Calls API GetAsyncKeyState and returns its return value.
member.remarks: If returns < 0, the key is pressed. This key state changes when the OS receives the key down or up notification and before the active app receives the notification. If a key is blocked by a low-level hook, its state does not change. Then it's impossible to detect whether the key is physically pressed.

member.name: M:Au.Keyb.IsPressed(Au.Types.KKey)
member.summary: Returns true if the specified key or mouse button is pressed.
member.remarks: Calls API GetKeyState.

member.name: M:Au.Keyb.WaitForNoModifierKeys(System.Double,Au.Types.KMod)
member.summary: Waits while some modifier keys (Ctrl, Shift, Alt, Win) are in pressed state (see ).
member.param: Check only these keys. Default - all.

member.name: M:Au.Keyb.WaitForNoModifierKeysAndMouseButtons(System.Double,Au.Types.KMod,Au.Types.MButtons)
member.summary: Waits while some modifier keys (Ctrl, Shift, Alt, Win) or mouse buttons are in pressed state.
member.param: Check only these keys. Default - all.
Check only these buttons. Default - all.

member.name: M:Au.Keyb.WaitForReleased(System.Double,Au.Types.KKey[])
member.summary: Waits while the specified keys or/and mouse buttons are in pressed state.
member.param: One or more keys or/and mouse buttons. Waits until all are released. Can be string like with , without operators.

member.name: M:Au.Keyb.WaitForHotkey(System.Double,Au.Types.KHotkey,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Registers a temporary hotkey and waits for it.
member.param: Also wait until hotkey modifier keys released.
member.remarks: Uses ; it uses API RegisterHotKey. Fails if the hotkey is currently registered by this or another application or used by Windows. Also if F12.

member.name: M:Au.Keyb.WaitForKey(System.Double,Au.Types.KKey,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Waits for key-down or key-up event of the specified key.
member.param: Wait for this key. Can be a single-key string like with .
Wait for key-up event.
Make the event invisible for other apps. If is true, makes the down event invisible too, if it comes while waiting for the up event.
member.remarks: Unlike , waits for key event, not for key state. Uses low-level keyboard hook. Can wait for any single key. See also .

example.code: Keyb.WaitForKey(0, KKey.Ctrl, up: false, block: true); Print("Ctrl");
Keyb.WaitForKey(0, "Ctrl", up: false, block: true); Print("Ctrl");

member.name: M:Au.Keyb.WaitForKey(System.Double,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Waits for key-down or key-up event of any key, and gets the key code.
member.returns: Returns the key code. On timeout returns 0 if is negative; else exception. For modifier keys returns the left or right key code, for example LCtrl/RCtrl, not Ctrl.

example.code: var key = Keyb.WaitForKey(0, up: true, block: true); Print(key);

member.name: M:Au.Keyb.Misc.ParseHotkeyString(System.String,Au.Types.KMod@,Au.Types.KKey@)
member.summary: Converts hotkey string to and . For example, if s is "Ctrl+Left", sets mod=KMod.Ctrl, key=KKey.Left. Returns false if the string is invalid.
member.remarks: Key names are like with . Must be single non-modifier key, preceded by zero or more of modifier keys Ctrl, Shift, Alt, Win, all joined with +. Valid hotkey examples: "A", "a", "7", "F12", ".", "End", "Ctrl+D", "Ctrl+Alt+Shift+Win+Left", " Ctrl + U ". Invalid hotkey examples: null, "", "A+B", "Ctrl+A+K", "A+Ctrl", "Ctrl+Shift", "Ctrl+", "NoSuchKey", "tab".

member.name: M:Au.Keyb.Key(System.Object[])
member.summary: Sends virtual keystrokes to the active window. Also can send text, wait, etc.
member.param:
Any number of arguments of these types:
string one or more key names separated by spaces or operators. More info in Remarks. Example: Key("Enter A Ctrl+A"); See .
string after 'keys' string literal text. When there are several strings in sequence, they are interpreted as keys, text, keys, text... Example: Key("keys", "text", "keys", "text", 500, "keys", "text", "keys", KKey.Back, "keys", "text"); Function is the same as Key, but the first parameter is text. To send text can be used keys or clipboard, depending on and text. See .
a single key. Example: Key("Shift+", KKey.Left, "*3"); is the same as Key("Shift+Left*3");. See .
int milliseconds to sleep. Max 10000. Example: Key("Left", 500, "Right"); See .
callback function. Example: Action click = () => Mouse.Click(); Key("Shift+", click); See .
null or "" nothing. Example: Key("keys", 500, "", "text");
(int, bool) a single key, specified using scan code and extended-key flag. Example: Key("", "key F1:", (0x3B, false)); See .
(KKey, int, bool) a single key, specified using and/or scan code and extended-key flag. Example: Key("", "numpad Enter:", (KKey.Enter, 0, true)); See .
member.exception: An argument is of an unsupported type or has an invalid value, for example an unknown key name.
member.remarks:
Generates virtual keystrokes. Uses API SendInput. It works almost like real keyboard.
Usually keys are specified in string, like in this example: Key("A F2 Ctrl+Shift+A Enter*2"); //keys A, F2, Ctrl+Shift+A, Enter Enter
Key names:
Group Keys Info
Named keys
Modifier: Alt, Ctrl, Shift, Win Right side: RAlt, RCtrl, RShift, RWin Lock: CapsLock, NumLock, ScrollLock Function: F1-F24 Arrow: Down, Left, Right, Up Other: Back, Del, End, Enter, Esc, Home, Ins, Menu, PgDown, PgUp, PrtSc, Space, Tab
Start with an uppercase character. Only the first 3 characters are significant; others can be any ASCII letters. For example, can be "Back", "Bac", "Backspace" or "BACK", but not "back" or "Ba" or "Back5".
Alternative key names: AltGr (RAlt), App (Menu), PageDown, PageUp, PrintScreen (PrtSc).
Text keys
Alphabetic: A-Z (or a-z) Number: 0-9 Numeric keypad: #/ #* #- #+ #. #0-#9 Other: =, ` - [ ] \ ; ' , . /
Spaces between keys are optional, except for uppercase A-Z. For example, can be "A B", "a b", "A b" or "ab", but not "AB" or "Ab".
For ` - [ ] \ ; ' , . / also can be used ~ _ { } | : " < > ?.
Other keys Names of enum or members. Start with an uppercase character. Example: Key("BrowserBack", KKey.BrowserBack);
Forbidden Fn, Ctrl+Alt+Del, Win+L, some other Programs cannot press these keys.
Special characters Operator: + * ( ) $ Numpad key prefix: # Reserved: ! @ % ^ &
These characters cannot be used as keys. Use = 8 9 0 4 3 1 2 5 6 7.
Operators:
Operator Examples Description
+ "Ctrl+Shift+A"
"Alt+E+P" The same as "Ctrl*down Shift*down A Shift*up Ctrl*up" and "Alt*down E*down P E*up Alt*up".
+() "Alt+(E P)" The same as "Alt*down E P Alt*up". Inside () cannot be used + or another +().
*down "Ctrl*down" Press key and don't release.
*up "Ctrl*up" Release key.
*number "Left*3" Press key repeatedly, like "Left Left Left". See .
$ "$text" $ is the same as Shift+.
Operators and related keys can be in separate arguments. Examples: Key("Shift+", KKey.A); Key(KKey.A, "*3");.
Uses :
Option Default Changed
false. Blocks user-pressed keys. Sends them afterwards. If the last argument is 'sleep', stops blocking before executing it; else stops blocking after executing all arguments. true. Does not block user-pressed keys. It can be dangerous.
false. If the CapsLock key is toggled, untoggles it temporarily (presses it before and after). true. Does not touch the CapsLock key. Alphabetic keys of 'keys' arguments can depend on CapsLock. Text of 'text' arguments doesn't depend on CapsLock, unless is .
false. Releases modifier keys (Alt, Ctrl, Shift, Win) if pressed. Does it only at the start; later they cannot interfere, unless is true. true. Does not touch modifier keys. It can be dangerous.
0 ms. 0 - 1000. Changes the speed for 'text' arguments (makes slower).
1 ms. 0 - 1000. Changes the speed for 'keys' arguments (makes slower if >1).
5 ms. 0 - 1000. Changes the speed of Ctrl+V keys when text is pasted using the clipboard.
10 ms. 0 - 10000. Tip: to sleep finally, also can be used code like this: Key("keys", 1000);.
Keys (send keys and Shift) or Paste (use clipboard).
300. This option is used for 'text' arguments. If text length >= this value, uses the clipboard. >=0.
false. true. This option is used for 'text' arguments when using the clipboard.
true. Restore clipboard data (by default only text). This option is used for 'text' arguments when using the clipboard. false. Don't restore clipboard data.
null. Callback function that can modify options depending on active window etc.
When you don't want to use or modify , use a variable instead of this function. Example: new Keyb(null).Add("keys", "text").Send();. More examples in topic.
This function does not wait until the target app receives and processes sent keystrokes and text; there is no reliable way to know it. It just adds small delays depending on options ( etc). If need, change options or add 'sleep' arguments or wait after calling this function. Sending text through the clipboard normally does not have these problems.
This function should not be used to automate windows of own thread. In most cases it works, but strange problems are possible, because while waiting it gets/dispatches all messages/events/etc. It's better to call it from another thread. See the last example.
Administrator and uiAccess processes don't receive keystrokes sent by standard user processes. See UAC.
The mouse button codes/names (eg ) cannot be used to click. For it can be used callback, like in the "Ctrl+click" example.

member.name: M:Au.Keyb.Text(System.String,System.Object[])
member.summary: Sends text to the active window, using virtual keystrokes or the clipboard. Also can send non-text keystrokes.
member.param: Text to send.
Optional more parameters. The same as with . Can be used for example to press non-text keys, wait, send more text.
member.exception: An argument in is of an unsupported type or has an invalid value, for example an unknown key name.
member.remarks: This function is identical to , except: the first parameter is literal text (not keys). This example shows the difference: Key("keys", "text", "keys", "text"); Text("text", "keys", "text", "keys");. To send text can be used keys or clipboard, depending on and text. More info in topic.

member.name: T:Au.OsdWindow
member.summary: Transparent window that can be used for on-screen display. Derived classes on it can draw non-transparent text, rectangle, image, anything.

member.name: M:Au.OsdWindow.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Destroys the OSD window.

member.name: M:Au.OsdWindow.Dispose
member.summary: Destroys the OSD window.

member.name: M:Au.OsdWindow.Close
member.summary: Destroys the OSD window.

member.name: P:Au.OsdWindow.Handle
member.summary: OSD window handle or default(Wnd).

member.name: P:Au.OsdWindow.IsHandleCreated
member.summary: Returns true if the OSD window is created.

member.name: M:Au.OsdWindow.Redraw
member.summary: Redraws the OSD window immediately. Does nothing it is not created or not visible.

member.name: M:Au.OsdWindow.Invalidate
member.summary: Sets to redraw the OSD window later. Does nothing it is not created or not visible.

member.name: P:Au.OsdWindow.Opacity
member.summary: Gets or sets the opacity of the OSD window, from 0 to 1. If 1 (default), completely opaque. If 0, pixels of are transparent, others opaque. If between 0 and 1, partially transparent.
member.remarks: This property can be changed after creating OSD window.

member.name: P:Au.OsdWindow.TransparentColor
member.summary: Gets or sets transparent color, default 0xF5F4F5. Pixels of this color will be transparent, unless is not 0.
member.remarks: This property cannot be changed after creating OSD window. Note: when used for transparent text, text edges are blended with this color, and it can become visible if the color is not chosen carefully.

member.name: P:Au.OsdWindow.Rect
member.summary: Gets or sets OSD window size and position in screen.
member.remarks: This property can be changed after creating OSD window.

member.name: P:Au.OsdWindow.Visible
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the OSD window is visible. The 'set' function calls (it creates OSD window if need) or (it does not destroy the OSD window).

member.name: M:Au.OsdWindow.Show
member.summary: Shows the OSD window. Creates if need.
member.remarks: In any case, also moves the window to the top of the Z order.

member.name: M:Au.OsdWindow.Hide
member.summary: Hides the OSD window. Does not destroy; use or for it. Does nothing if not created or not visible.

member.name: M:Au.OsdWindow.WndProc(Au.Wnd,System.Int32,Au.Types.LPARAM,Au.Types.LPARAM)
member.summary: Called when the OSD window receives a message. If your derived class overrides this function, it must call base.WndProc and return its return value, except when don't need default processing.

member.name: M:Au.OsdWindow.OnPaint(System.Drawing.Graphics,System.Drawing.Rectangle)
member.summary: Called when the OSD window must be drawn or redrawn. Derived classes should override this function and draw anything. Don't need to call base.OnPaint of , it does nothing.
member.remarks: If is 0 (default), is filled with . Pixels of this color will be transparent. The base class draws only non-transparent areas.

member.name: P:Au.OsdWindow.Shadow
member.summary: If true, the OSD window will have shadow.
member.remarks: This property cannot be changed after creating OSD window.

member.name: P:Au.OsdWindow.ClickToClose
member.summary: If true, the OSD window receive mouse messages. Only completely transparent areas don't. The user can click to close the OSD (left, right or middle button).
member.remarks: This property cannot be changed after creating OSD window.

member.name: P:Au.OsdWindow.Name
member.summary: OSD window name. Optional, default null.
member.remarks: This text is invisible. Can be used to find OSD window. The class name is "Au.OSD"; if with shadow - "Au.OSD2".
This property cannot be changed after creating OSD window.

member.name: M:Au.OsdWindow.CloseAll(System.String)

member.name: M:Au.WinImage.Find(Au.Types.WIArea,System.Object,Au.Types.WIFlags,System.Int32,System.Func{Au.WinImage,Au.Types.WIAlso})
member.summary: Finds image(s) or color(s) displayed in window or other area.
member.returns: Returns object containing the rectangle of the found image. Returns null if not found. See example.
member.param:
Where to search. Can be a window/control, accessible object, another image or a rectangle in screen.
- window or control. The search area is its client area.
- accessible object.
- another image. These flags are invalid: .
- a rectangle area in screen. These flags are invalid: .
- can contain Wnd, Acc or Bitmap. Also allows to specify a rectangle in it, which makes the search area smaller and the function faster. Example: WinImage.Find((w, (left, top, width, height)), "image.png");.

Image or color to find. Can be of type:
string - path of .png or .bmp file. If not full path, uses . If the file does not exist, looks in resources of apdomain's entry assembly. For example, looks for Project.Properties.Resources.X if file @"C:\X.png" not found. Alternatively you can use code like using(var b = Project.Properties.Resources.X) WinImage.Find(w, b);.
string that starts with "image:" or "~:" - Base64-encoded .png or .bmp image embedded in script. If "image:", it is .png file data, else it is compressed .bmp file data. Can be created with function Au.Controls.ImageUtil.ImageToString (in Au.Controls.dll).
int, ColorInt or Color - color. Int must be in 0xRRGGBB format. Alpha is not used.
Bitmap - image object in memory.
IEnumerable of string, int/ColorInt/Color, Bitmap or object - multiple images or colors. Action - find any. To create a different action can be used callback function (parameter ).
Icons are not supported directly, but you can use or . Transparent and partially transparent pixels are not compared. For example, when you capture a non-rectangular area image, the image actually is rectangular, but pixels outside of its captured area are transparent and therefore not compared. Also you can draw transparent areas with an image editor that supports it, for example Paint.NET.

Maximal allowed color difference. Use to to find images that have slightly different colors than the specified image. Can be 0 - 250, but should be as small as possible. Applied to each color component (red, green, blue) of each pixel.
member.exception: An argument is of unsupported type or is/contains a null/invalid value. Image or area is a bottom-up Bitmap object (see ). Such bitmaps are unusual in .NET (GDI+), but can be created by Image.FromHbitmap (instead use ).
The specified file does not exist.
Depending on string format, exceptions of , , .
member.remarks:
To create code for this function, use dialog "Find image or color in window". It is form Au.Tools.Form_WinImage in Au.Tools.dll.
The speed mostly depends on: 1. The size of the search area. Use the smallest possible area (control or accessible object or rectangle in window like (w, rectangle)). 2. Flag . Usually makes several times faster. With this flag the speed depends on window. 3. Video driver. Can be much slower if incorrect, generic or virtual PC driver is used. Flag should help. 4. . Should be as small as possible.
If flag is not used, the search area must be visible on the screen. If it is covered by other windows, the function will search in these windows.
The function can only find images that exactly match the specified image. With it can find images with slightly different colors and brightness. It cannot find images with different shapes.
This function is not the best way to find objects when the script is intended for long use or for use on multiple computers or must be very reliable. Because it may fail to find the image after are changed some settings - system theme, application theme, text size (DPI), font smoothing (if the image contains text), etc. Also are possible various unexpected temporary conditions that may distort or hide the image, for example adjacent window shadow, a tooltip or some temporary window. If possible, in such scripts instead use other functions, eg find control or accessible object.

member.name: T:Au.Opt
member.summary: Options used by some functions of this library.
member.remarks:
Some frequently used static functions of this library have some options (settings). For example allows to change speed, text sending method, etc. Passing options as parameters in each call usually isn't what you want to do in automation scripts. Instead you can set options using static properties. This class contains several groups of options for functions of various classes. See examples.
There are two sets of identical or similar options - in class Opt and in its nested class :
Opt - thread-static options (each thread has its own instance). Functions of this library use them. You can change or change-restore them anywhere in script. Initial options are automatically copied from Opt.Static when that group of options (Key, Mouse, etc) is used first time in that thread (explicitly or by library functions).
Opt.Static - static options. Contains initial property values for Opt. Normally you change them in your script template (in script initialization code) or at the very start of script. Don't change later, it's not thread-safe.

member.name: P:Au.Opt.Key
member.summary: Options for keyboard and clipboard functions (classes , and functions that use them).
member.remarks: Each thread has its own Opt.Key instance. It inherits options from . Also can be used when creating instances. See the second example.

member.name: P:Au.Opt.Mouse
member.summary: Options for mouse functions (class and functions that use it).
member.remarks: Each thread has its own Opt.Mouse instance. It inherits options from .

example.code: Opt.Mouse.ClickSpeed = 100; Mouse.Click();

member.name: P:Au.Opt.Debug
member.summary: Options for showing run-time warnings and other info that can be useful to find problems in code at run time.
member.remarks: Each thread has its own Opt.Debug instance. It inherits options from .

member.name: P:Au.Opt.WaitFor
member.summary: Options for 'wait for' functions.
member.remarks: Each thread has its own Opt.WaitFor instance. There is no Opt.Static.WaitFor. Most 'wait for' functions of this library use these options. Functions of .NET classes don't.

member.name: T:Au.Opt.Static
member.summary: Default properties of each thread.
member.remarks: You can change these options at the start of your script or in the static constructor of script's class. Don't change later.

member.name: P:Au.Opt.Static.Key
member.summary: Default option values for of each thread.
member.remarks: Also can be used when creating instances. See the second example.
member.example:
static MyScriptClass() { Opt.Static.Key.KeySpeed = 10; } //static constructor ... Key("Tab Ctrl+V"); //uses Opt.Key, which is implicitly copied from Opt.Static.Key
Use a Keyb instance.
var k = new Keyb(Opt.Static.Key); //create new Keyb instance and copy options from Opt.Static.Key to it k.Options.KeySpeed = 100; //changes option of k but not of Opt.Static.Key k.Add("Tab Ctrl+V").Send(); //uses options of k

member.name: P:Au.Opt.Static.Mouse
member.summary: Default option values for of each thread.

example.code: static MyScriptClass() { Opt.Static.Mouse.ClickSpeed = 10; } //static constructor, for example in script template ... Mouse.Click(); //uses Opt.Mouse, which is implicitly copied from Opt.Static.Mouse

member.name: P:Au.Opt.Static.Debug
member.summary: Default option values for of each thread.

example.code: Opt.Static.Debug.Verbose = false;

member.summary: Makes easy to restore current options of this thread. See example.

member.summary: Makes easy to restore current of this thread. See example.

member.name: T:Au.Output
member.summary: Writes text to the output window, console or log file.
member.remarks:
When , Print, etc is called, where the text goes:
If redirected, to wherever it is redirected. See .
Else if using log file ( not null), writes to the file.
Else if using console ( returns true), writes to console.
Else if using local (in this appdomain), writes to it.
Else if exists global (in any process/appdomain), writes to it.
Else nowhere.

member.name: P:Au.Output.IsConsoleProcess
member.summary: Returns true if this is a console process.

member.name: P:Au.Output.IsWritingToConsole
member.summary: Returns true if is writing to console, false if to the output window or log file. Assuming that is not changed.
member.remarks:
Does not write to console in these cases:
is false.
is true.
is not null.
The startup info of this process tells to not show console window and to not redirect the standard output.

member.name: P:Au.Output.IgnoreConsole
member.summary: If true, Write and related functions in console process don't not use the console window. Then everything is like in non-console process.

member.name: M:Au.Output.Clear
member.summary: Clears the output window or console text (if ) or log file (if not null).

member.name: M:Au.Output.Write(System.String)
member.summary: Writes string + "\r\n" to the output window or console (if ) or log file (if not null).

member.name: P:Au.Output.Writer
member.summary: Gets or sets object that actually writes text when is called Output.Write, Print and similar functions.
member.remarks: If you want to redirect, modify or just monitor output text, use code like in the example. It is known as "output redirection". Redirection is applied to whole appdomain, and does not affect other appdomains. Redirection affects Output.Write, Print and similar functions, also Output.RedirectConsoleOutput and Output.RedirectDebugOutput. It does not affect Output.WriteDirectly and Output.Clear. Don't call Output.Write, Print etc in method WriteLine(string) of your writer class. It would call itself and create stack overflow. But you can call Output.WriteDirectly.

member.name: T:Au.Output._OutputWriter
member.summary: Our default writer class for the Writer property.

member.name: M:Au.Output.WriteDirectly(System.String)
member.summary: Writes string value + "\r\n" to the output window or console (if ) or log file (if not null). Unlike Output.Write, Print etc, the string is not passed to .

member.name: P:Au.Output.RedirectConsoleOutput
member.summary: Let Console.WriteX methods in non-console process write to the same destination as Output.Write etc.
member.remarks: Console.Write will write line, like Console.WriteLine. Console.Clear will not clear output; it will throw exception.

member.name: P:Au.Output.RedirectDebugOutput
member.summary: Let Debug.WriteX and Trace.WriteX methods write to the same destination as Output.Write etc.
member.remarks: Tip: To write to the output window even in console process, set Output.IgnoreConsole=true; before calling this method first time.

member.name: P:Au.Output.LogFile
member.summary: Sets log file path. When set (not null), text passed to Output.Write, Print and similar functions will be written to the file. Assuming that is not changed. If value is null - restores default behavior.
member.remarks:
The first Write etc call (in this appdomain) creates or opens the file and deletes old content if the file already exists. Multiple appdomains cannot use the same file. If the file is open for writing, Write makes unique filename and changes LogFile value.
Also supports mailslots. For LogFile use mailslot name, as documented in CreateMailslot. Multiple appdomains and processes can use the same mailslot.
member.exception: The 'set' function throws this exception if the value is not full path and not null.

member.name: P:Au.Output.LogFileTimestamp
member.summary: Let Write etc also add current time when using log file (see ). The time is local, not UTC.

member.name: M:Au.Output._LogFile.Open
member.summary: Opens LogFile file handle for writing. Uses CREATE_ALWAYS, GENERIC_WRITE, FILE_SHARE_READ.
member.remarks: Multiple appdomains cannot use the same file. Each appdomain overwrites it when opens first time.

member.name: M:Au.Output._LogFile.WriteLine(System.String)
member.summary: Writes s + "\r\n" and optionally timestamp.
member.remarks: If fails to write to file: Sets LogFile=null, which closes file handle. Writes a warning and s to the output window or console.

member.name: T:Au.Regex_
member.summary: PCRE regular expression.
member.remarks:
PCRE is a regular expression library: . PCRE regular expression syntax: full, short. Some websites with tutorials and info: rexegg, regular-expressions.info.
This class is an alternative to the .NET class. The regular expression syntax is similar. PCRE has some features unavailable in .NET, and vice versa. In most cases PCRE is about 2 times faster. You can use any of these classes. Functions of class support only PCRE.
Terms used in this documentation and in names of functions and types:
regular expression Regular expression string. Also known as pattern.
subject string The string in which to search for the regular expression. Also known as input string.
match The part (substring) of the subject string that matches the regular expression.
groups Regular expression parts enclosed in (). Except non-capturing parts, like (?:...) and (?options). Also known as capturing group, capturing subpattern. Often term group also is used for group matches.
group match The part (substring) of the subject string that matches the group. Also known as captured substring.
This library uses an unmanaged code dll AuCpp.dll that contains PCRE code. This class is a managed wrapper for it. The main PCRE API functions used by this class are pcre2_compile and pcre2_match. The Regex_ constructor calls pcre2_compile and stores the compiled code in the variable. Other Regex_ functions call pcre2_match. Compiling to native code (JIT) is not supported.
A Regex_ variable can be used by multiple threads simultaneously.
Also there are several String extension methods that use this class. The string variable is the subject string. These methods create and use cached Regex_ instances for speed. The Regex_ constructor does not use caching.

member.name: M:Au.Regex_.#ctor(System.String,Au.Types.RXFlags)
member.summary:
Compiles regular expression string.
PCRE regular expression syntax: full, short.
member.param: Regular expression. Cannot be null.
Options. Default 0. Flag UTF is implicitly added if contains non-ASCII characters and there is no flag NEVER_UTF.
member.exception: Invalid regular expression. Or failed to compile it for some other reason (unlikely).
member.remarks:
Calls PCRE API function pcre2_compile.
Examples in class help: .

member.name: P:Au.Regex_.Callout
member.summary: Sets callout callback function.
member.remarks: Callouts can be used to: 1. Track the matching progress. 2. Get all instances of a group that can match multiple times. 3. Evaluate and reject some matches or match parts. 4. Etc. The callback function is called by , , , , and similar functions, when they reach callout points in regular expression. To insert callout points use (?C), (?C1), (?C2), (?C'name') etc or pass flag AUTO_CALLOUT to the constructor. More info in PCRE help topic pcre2callout. See also:

member.name: M:Au.Regex_.GroupNumberFromName(System.String)
member.summary: Finds a named group and returns its 1-based index. Returns -1 if not found.
member.param: Group name. In regular expression, to set name of group (text), use (?<NAME>text).
member.exception: More than 1 group have this name.

member.name: M:Au.Regex_.IsMatch(System.String,Au.Types.RXMore)
member.summary: Returns true if string matches this regular expression.
member.param: Subject string. If null, always returns false, even if the regular expression matches empty string.
member.exception: The PCRE API function pcre2_match failed. Unlikely.
member.remarks:
If partial match, returns true too. Partial match is possible if used a PARTIAL_ flag.
This function is similar to .

member.name: M:Au.Regex_.Match(System.String,Au.Types.RXMatch@,Au.Types.RXMore)
member.summary: Returns true if string matches this regular expression. Gets match info as .
member.param: Subject string. If null, always returns false, even if the regular expression matches empty string.
Receives match info. Read more in Remarks.
member.exception: The PCRE API function pcre2_match failed. Unlikely.
member.remarks:
If full match, returns true, and contains the match and all groups that exist in the regular expressions. If partial match, returns true, and contains the match without groups. Partial match is possible if used a PARTIAL_ flag. If no match, returns false, and normally is null. But if a mark is available, is an object with two valid properties - (false) and ; other properties have undefined values or throw exception.
This function is similar to .

member.name: M:Au.Regex_.MatchG(System.String,Au.Types.RXGroup@,System.Int32,Au.Types.RXMore)
member.summary: Returns true if string matches this regular expression. Gets whole match or some group, as (index, length, value).
member.param: Subject string. If null, always returns false, even if the regular expression matches empty string.
Receives match info.
Group number (1-based index) of result. If 0 (default) - whole match. See also .
member.exception: The PCRE API function pcre2_match failed. Unlikely.
member.remarks: This function is a simplified version of . If full match, returns true, and contains the match or the specifed group. If partial match, returns true too. Partial match is possible if used a PARTIAL_ flag. Then cannot get groups, therefore should be 0. If no match, returns false, and is empty.

member.name: M:Au.Regex_.MatchS(System.String,System.String@,System.Int32,Au.Types.RXMore)
member.summary: Returns true if string matches this regular expression. Gets whole match or some group, as string.
member.param: Subject string. If null, always returns false, even if the regular expression matches empty string.
Receives the match value.
Group number (1-based index) of result. If 0 (default) - whole match. See also .

member.name: M:Au.String_.Like_(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Compares this string with a string that possibly contains wildcard characters. Returns true if the strings match.
Wildcard characters: * - zero or more of any characters. ? - any character.
member.param: This string. If null, returns false. If "", returns true if pattern is "" or "*".
String that possibly contains wildcard characters. Cannot be null. If "", returns true if this string is "". If "*", always returns true except when this string is null.
Case-insensitive.
member.remarks: Like all String_ functions, performs ordinal comparison, ie does not depend on current culture. Much faster than Regex.IsMatch and not much slower than Equals_, EndsWith_, IndexOf_ etc.

member.name: M:Au.String_.Like_(System.String,System.Boolean,System.String[])
member.summary: Calls for each wildcard pattern specified in the argument list until it returns true. Returns 1-based index of matching pattern, or 0 if none.
member.param: Case-insensitive.
One or more wildcard strings. The array and strings cannot be null.

member.name: M:Au.String_.ToInt_(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32@,Au.Types.STIFlags)
member.summary: Converts part of string to int. Returns the int value, or 0 if fails to convert.
member.param: Offset in this string where to start parsing.
Receives offset in string where the number part ends. If fails to convert, receives 0.
member.remarks:
Fails to convert when string is null, "", does not begin with a number or the number is too big.
Unlike int.Parse and Convert.ToInt32: The number in string can be followed by more text, like "123text". Has startIndex parameter that allows to get number from middle, like "text123text". Gets the end of the number part. No exception when cannot convert. Supports hexadecimal format, like "0x1A", case-insensitive. Much faster.
The number in string can begin with ASCII spaces, tabs or newlines, like " 5". The number in string can be with "-" or "+", like "-5", but not like "- 5". Fails if the number is greater than +- uint.MaxValue (0xffffffff). The return value becomes negative if the number is greater than int.MaxValue, for example "0xffffffff" is -1, but it becomes correct if assigned to uint (need cast). Does not support non-integer numbers; for example, for "3.5E4" returns 3 and sets numberEndIndex=startIndex+1.
member.exception: startIndex is less than 0 or greater than string length.

member.name: M:Au.String_.ToInt_(System.String,System.Int32,Au.Types.STIFlags)
member.summary: This overload does not have parameter numberEndIndex.

member.name: M:Au.String_.ToInt_(System.String)
member.summary: This overload does not have parameters.

member.summary: Converts part of string to long. Returns the long value, or 0 if fails to convert.
member.param: Offset in this string where to start parsing.
Receives offset in string where the number part ends. If fails to convert, receives 0.
member.remarks:
Fails to convert when string is null, "", does not begin with a number or the number is too big.
Unlike long.Parse and Convert.ToInt64: The number in string can be followed by more text, like "123text". Has startIndex parameter that allows to get number from middle, like "text123text". Gets the end of the number part. No exception when cannot convert. Supports hexadecimal format, like "0x1A", case-insensitive. Much faster.
The number in string can begin with ASCII spaces, tabs or newlines, like " 5". The number in string can be with "-" or "+", like "-5", but not like "- 5". Fails if the number is greater than +- ulong.MaxValue (0xffffffffffffffff). The return value becomes negative if the number is greater than long.MaxValue, for example "0xffffffffffffffff" is -1, but it becomes correct if assigned to ulong (need cast). Does not support non-integer numbers; for example, for "3.5E4" returns 3 and sets numberEndIndex=startIndex+1.
member.exception: startIndex is less than 0 or greater than string length.

member.name: T:Au.StringSegment
member.summary: An optimized representation of a substring (any part of a string).
member.remarks:
The main properties are: - the string containing the substring; - the start index of the substring in the string; substring length. There is no string object for the substring itself; however and some other functions allocate and return a new string object.
One of ways to create StringSegment instances is to split a string with .
Don't use the default constructor (parameterless). Then Buffer is null and the behavior of functions is undefined. Other constructors throw exception if the string is null.
Functions throw ArgumentOutOfRangeException, ArgumentNullException, NullReferenceException or IndexOutOfRangeException exception when an argument is invalid.

member.name: T:Au.InterDomainVariables
member.summary: Inter-domain variables. Allows to share values by all app domains of this process.
member.remarks: Similar to environment variables, but supports more types and does not inherit parent process variables; the speed is similar. Supports not all types. The type must have one of these properties: 1. Derived from MarshalByRefObject. The stored value is a virtual reference (proxy), not a copy. The owner domain must be still alive when other domains access (call methods etc) the retrieved value, else AppDomainUnloadedException. 2. Has [Serializable] attribute. The stored value is a copy, not reference. For example int, IntPtr, string, arrays, List, Dictionary.

member.name: M:Au.InterDomainVariables.SetVariable(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Adds or modifies an inter-domain variable.
member.param: Name. Can be any unique string, for example a GUID string. Case-sensitive.
Value.
member.exception: The type is not supported because is neither serializable nor MarshalByRefObject-derived.

member.name: M:Au.InterDomainVariables.GetVariable(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the value of an inter-domain variable. Returns null if the variable does not exist. Else returns the value as object; need a cast.
member.param: Name. Case-sensitive.

member.name: M:Au.InterDomainVariables.GetVariable``1(System.String,``0@)
member.summary: Gets the value of an inter-domain variable. Returns true if the variable exists and is not null.
member.param: Name. Case-sensitive.
Receives the value. If the variable does not exist, receives the default value of that type (for reference types it is null).

member.name: M:Au.InterDomainVariables.GetVariable``1(System.String,System.Func{``0})
member.summary: Gets the value of an inter-domain variable. If the variable does not exist or is null, calls a callback function that provides an initial value; then sets the variable = the initial value. Thread-safe.
member.param: Name. Case-sensitive.
A callback function delegate (eg lambda) that is called when the variable does not exist or is null. It must return an initial value.
member.exception: The type is not supported because is neither serializable nor MarshalByRefObject-derived.
member.remarks: Be careful with types derived from MarshalByRefObject. If the object does not exist, your callback function creates it in this appdomain. Maybe this appdomain is not where you want it to live. Instead use SetVariable and another overload of GetVariable.

example.code: int test = InterDomainVariables.GetVariable("test", () => 10);

member.name: M:Au.InterDomainVariables.DefaultDomainVariable``1(System.String,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Gets a reference to an object that lives in default appdomain. Auto-creates new object there if does not exist. The object can be used in any appdomain. When a non-default domain calls its methods, the call is marshaled to the default domain and executed there.
member.typeparam: The type must be derived from MarshalByRefObject and have default constructor.
member.param: Inter-domain variable name. Any unique string. Case-sensitive.
Receives true if now created new object, false if the object alrady existed.
member.remarks: Thread-safe.

member.name: M:Au.InterDomainVariables.DefaultDomainVariable``1(System.String)
member.summary: The same as , just does not have the bool parameter.

member.name: T:Au.Files
member.summary: File system functions.
member.remarks: Works with files and directories. Disk drives like @"C:\" or "C:" are directories too. Extends .NET file system classes such as and . Many functions of this class can be used instead of existing similar .NET functions that are slow, limited or unreliable. Most functions support only full path. Most of them throw ArgumentException if passed a filename or relative path, ie in "current directory". Using current directory is unsafe; it was relevant only in DOS era. Most functions support extended-length paths (longer than 259). Such local paths should have @"\\?\" prefix, like @"\\?\C:\...". Such network path should be like @"\\?\UNC\server\share\...". See , . Many functions support long paths even without prefix.

member.name: T:Au.Files.Misc
member.summary: Miscellaneous file/directory functions.

member.name: T:Au.Files.Misc.FileId

member.remarks: Can be used with files and directories. To get it, use . There are many different ways to specify path to the same file or directory. To determine whether two paths represent the same file, get and compare their FileId.
