member.summary: Temporarily disables file system redirection, to allow this 32-bit process access the 64-bit System32 directory.

member.name: M:Au.Files.Misc.DisableRedirection.Disable
member.summary: If Ver.Is32BitProcessOn64BitOS, calls API Wow64DisableWow64FsRedirection, which disables file system redirection. The caller can call this without checking OS and process bitness. This function checks it and it is fast. Always call or Dispose, for example in finally{}, or use using (this struct implements IDisposable). Not calling it is more dangerous than a memory leak. It is not called by GC.

member.name: M:Au.Files.Misc.DisableRedirection.Revert
member.summary: If redirected, calls API Wow64RevertWow64FsRedirection.

member.name: M:Au.Files.Misc.DisableRedirection.IsSystem64PathIn32BitProcess(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if Ver.Is32BitProcessOn64BitOS is true and path starts with Folders.System. Most such paths are redirected, therefore you may want to disable redirection with this class.
member.param: Normalized path. This function does not normalize. Also it is unaware of @"\\?\".

member.name: M:Au.Files.Misc.DisableRedirection.GetNonRedirectedSystemPath(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: If Ver.Is32BitProcessOn64BitOS is true and path starts with Folders.System, replaces that path part with . It disables redirection to Folders.SystemX32 for that path.
member.param: Normalized path. This function does not normalize. Also it is unaware of @"\\?\".
Don't replace path if the file or directory exists in the redirected folder or does not exist in the non-redirected folder.

member.summary: Gets file system entry type - file, directory, and whether it exists. Returns NotFound (0) if does not exist or if fails to get attributes. Calls API GetFileAttributes.

member.name: M:Au.Files.ExistsAs2(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets file system entry type - file, directory, symbolic link, whether it exists and is accessible. Returns NotFound (0) if does not exist. Returns AccessDenied (< 0) if exists but this process cannot access it and get attributes. Calls API GetFileAttributes. The same as but provides more complete result. In most cases you can use ExistsAs, it's simpler.
member.param: Full path. Supports @"\.." etc. If useRawPath is false (default), supports environment variables (see ). Can be null.
Pass path to the API as it is, without any normalizing and full-path checking.
member.remarks: Supports . If you need exception when fails, instead call and check attributes Directory and ReparsePoint. Always use full path. If path is not full: if useRawPath is false (default) returns NotFound; if useRawPath is true, searches in "current directory".

member.name: M:Au.Files.ExistsAsAny(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns true if file or directory exists. Calls , which calls API GetFileAttributes.
member.param: Full path. Supports @"\.." etc. If useRawPath is false (default), supports environment variables (see ). Can be null.
Pass path to the API as it is, without any normalizing and full-path checking.
member.remarks: Supports . If you need exception when fails, instead call . Always use full path. If path is not full: if useRawPath is false (default) returns NotFound; if useRawPath is true, searches in "current directory". For symbolic links etc, returns true if the link exists. Does not care whether its target exists. Unlike and , this function returns true when the file exists but cannot get its attributes. Then ExistsAsAny(path) is not the same as ExistsAsFile(path) || ExistsAsDirectory(path).

member.summary: Returns true if file exists and is not a directory. Returns false if does not exist or if fails to get its attributes. Calls , which calls API GetFileAttributes.

Pass path to the API as it is, without any normalizing and full-path checking.
member.remarks: Supports . If you need exception when fails, instead call and check attribute Directory. Always use full path. If path is not full: if useRawPath is false (default) returns NotFound; if useRawPath is true, searches in "current directory". For symbolic links etc, returns true if the link exists and its target is not a directory. Does not care whether its target exists.

member.summary: Returns true if directory (folder or drive) exists. Returns false if does not exist or if fails to get its attributes. Calls , which calls API GetFileAttributes.
member.param: Full path. Supports @"\.." etc. If useRawPath is false (default), supports environment variables (see ). Can be null.
Pass path to the API as it is, without any normalizing and full-path checking.
member.remarks: Supports . If you need exception when fails, instead call and check attribute Directory. Always use full path. If path is not full: if useRawPath is false (default) returns NotFound; if useRawPath is true, searches in "current directory". For symbolic links etc, returns true if the link exists and its target is a directory. Does not care whether its target exists.

member.name: M:Au.Files.SearchPath(System.String,System.String[])
member.summary: Finds file or directory and returns full path. Returns null if cannot be found. If the path argument is full path, calls and returns normalized path if exists, null if not. Else searches in these places: 1. dirs, if used. 2. . 3. Calls API SearchPath, which searches in process directory, Windows system directories, current directory, PATH environment variable. The search order depends on API SetSearchPathMode or registry settings. 4. If path ends with ".exe", tries to get path from registry "App Paths" keys.
member.param: Full or relative path or just filename with extension. Supports network paths too.
0 or more directories where to search.

member.name: M:Au.Files.EnumDirectory(System.String,Au.Types.FEFlags,System.Func{Au.Types.FEFile,System.Boolean},System.Action{System.String})
member.summary: Gets names and other info of files and subdirectories in the specified directory. Returns an enumerable collection of objects containing the info. By default gets only direct children. Use flag to get all descendants.
member.param: Full path of the directory.

Callback function. Called for each file and subdirectory. If it returns false, the file/subdirectory is not included in results. This can be useful when EnumDirectory is called indirectly, for example by the Copy method. If you call it directly, you can instead skip processing the file in your foreach loop.

Callback function. Called when fails to get children of a subdirectory, when using flag . It receives the subdirectory path. It can call and throw an exception. If it does not throw an exception, the enumeration continues as if the directory is empty. If errorHandler not used, then throws exception. Read more in Remarks.
member.exception: directoryPath is invalid path or not full path.
Failed to get children of directoryPath or of a subdirectory. Read more in Remarks.
member.remarks:
Uses API FindFirstFile.
The paths that this function gets are normalized, ie may not start with exact directoryPath string. Expanded environment variables (see ), "..", DOS path etc. Paths longer than have @"\\?\" prefix (see ). For symbolic links and mounted folders, gets info of the link/folder and not of its target.
These errors are ignored: 1. Access denied (usually because of security permissions), unless used flag FailIfAccessDenied. 2. Missing target directory of a symbolic link or mounted folder. When an error is ignored, the function works as if that [sub]directory is empty; does not throw exception and does not call errorHandler.
Enumeration of a subdirectory starts immediately after the subdirectory itself is retrieved.

member.summary: Moves (changes path of) file or directory.

New full path. It is not the new parent directory. Use for it.
member.exception: path or newPath is not full path (see ).
The source file (path) does not exist or cannot be found.

In most cases uses API MoveFileEx. It's fast, because don't need to copy files. In these cases copies/deletes: destination is on another drive; need to merge directories. When need to copy, does not copy the security properties; sets default security properties.
Creates the destination directory if does not exist (see ). If path and newPath share the same parent directory, just renames the file.

member.name: M:Au.Files.Delete(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Deletes file or directory. Does nothing if it does not exist (no exception).
member.param: Full path.

Send to the Recycle Bin. If not possible, delete anyway. Why could be not possible: 1. The file is in a removable drive (most removables don't have a recycle bin). 2. The file is too large. 3. The path is too long. 4. The Recycle Bin is not used on that drive (it can be set in the Recycle Bin Properties dialog). 5. This process is non-UI-interactive, eg a service. 6. Unknown reasons. Note: it is much slower. To delete multiple, use .
member.remarks:
If directory, also deletes all its files and subdirectories. If fails to delete some, tries to delete as many as possible. Deletes read-only files too. Does not show any message boxes etc (confirmation, error, UAC consent, progress).
Some reasons why this function can fail: 1. The file is open (in any process). Or a file in the directory is open. 2. This process does not have security permissions to access or delete the file or directory or some of its descendants. 3. The directory is (or contains) the "current directory" (in any process).

member.name: M:Au.Files.Delete(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.String},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Deletes multiple files or/and directories. The same as , but faster when using Recycle Bin.
member.param: string array, List or other collection. Full paths.

member.remarks: This function is slow if the directory is large. Don't use this function for files (throws exception) and drives (instead use , it's fast and includes sizes of Recycle Bin and other protected hidden system directories).

To create the specified directory, calls API CreateDirectory or CreateDirectoryEx (if templateDirectory is not null).

member.name: T:Au.Shell
member.summary: Windows shell functions. Windows shell manages files, folders (directories), shortcuts and virtual objects such as Control Panel.

member.name: T:Au.Shell.Pidl
member.summary: Manages an ITEMIDLIST structure that is used with shell API to identify files and other shell objects. Like a file-system path, but not string.
member.remarks:
When calling shell API, virtual objects can be identified only by ITEMIDLIST. Some API also support "parsing name", which usually looks like "::{CLSID-1}\::{CLSID-2}". File-system objects can be identified by path as well as by ITEMIDLIST. URLs can be identified by URL as well as by ITEMIDLIST.
The ITEMIDLIST structure is in unmanaged memory, therefore this class implements IDisposable.

member.name: P:Au.Shell.Pidl.UnsafePtr
member.summary: Gets the ITEMIDLIST pointer (PIDL).
member.remarks: The ITEMIDLIST memory is managed by this variable and will be freed when disposing or GC-collecting it. Use where need.

member.name: P:Au.Shell.Pidl.HandleRef
member.summary: Gets the ITEMIDLIST pointer (PIDL).
member.remarks: Use to pass to API where the parameter type is HandlePtr. It is safer than because ensures that this variable will not be GC-collected during API call even if not referenced after the call.

member.name: P:Au.Shell.Pidl.IsNull
member.summary: Returns true if the PIDL is default(IntPtr).

member.name: M:Au.Shell.Pidl.#ctor(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Assigns an ITEMIDLIST to this variable.
member.param: ITEMIDLIST pointer (PIDL). It can be created by any API that creates ITEMIDLIST. They allocate the memory with API CoTaskMemAlloc. This variable will finally free it with Marshal.FreeCoTaskMem.

member.name: M:Au.Shell.Pidl.Dispose
member.summary: Frees the ITEMIDLIST with Marshal.FreeCoTaskMem and clears this variable.

member.name: M:Au.Shell.Pidl.Detach
member.summary: Gets the ITEMIDLIST and clears this variable so that it cannot be used and will not free the ITEMIDLIST memory. To free it use Marshal.FreeCoTaskMem.

member.name: M:Au.Shell.Pidl.FromString(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts string to ITEMIDLIST and creates new Pidl variable that holds it. Returns null if failed. Note: Pidl is disposable.
member.param: A file-system path or URL or shell object parsing name (see ) or ":: HexEncodedITEMIDLIST" (see ). Supports environment variables (see ).
If failed, throw AuException.
member.exception: Failed, and throwIfFailed is true. Probably invalid s.
member.remarks: Calls SHParseDisplayName, except when string is ":: HexEncodedITEMIDLIST". Never fails if s is ":: HexEncodedITEMIDLIST", even if it creates an invalid ITEMIDLIST.

member.name: M:Au.Shell.Pidl.LibFromString(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: The same as , just returns unmanaged ITEMIDLIST pointer (PIDL). Later need to free it with Marshal.FreeCoTaskMem.

member.name: M:Au.Shell.Pidl.ToShellString(Au.Types.Native.SIGDN,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts the ITEMIDLIST to file path or URL or shell object parsing name or display name, depending on stringType argument. Returns null if this variable does not have an ITEMIDLIST (eg disposed or detached). If failed, returns null or throws exception.
member.param: String format. Often used: Native.SIGDN.NORMALDISPLAY - returns object name without path. It is best to display in UI but cannot be parsed to create ITEMIDLIST again. Native.SIGDN.FILESYSPATH - returns path if the ITEMIDLIST identifies a file system object (file or directory). Else returns null. Native.SIGDN.URL - if URL, returns URL. If file system object, returns its path like "file:///C:/a/b.txt". Else returns null. Native.SIGDN.DESKTOPABSOLUTEPARSING - returns path (if file system object) or URL (if URL) or shell object parsing name (if virtual object eg Control Panel). Note: not all returned parsing names can actually be parsed to create ITEMIDLIST again, therefore usually it's better to use instead.
If failed, throw AuException.
member.remarks: Calls SHGetNameFromIDList.

member.name: M:Au.Shell.Pidl.LibToShellString(System.IntPtr,Au.Types.Native.SIGDN,System.Boolean)
member.summary: The same as , just uses an ITEMIDLIST pointer that is not stored in a Pidl variable.

member.name: M:Au.Shell.Pidl.ToString
member.summary: Converts the ITEMIDLIST to string. If it identifies an existing file-system object (file or directory), returns path. If URL, returns URL. Else returns ":: HexEncodedITEMIDLIST" (see ). Returns null if this variable does not have an ITEMIDLIST (eg disposed or detached).

member.name: M:Au.Shell.Pidl.LibToString(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The same as , just uses an ITEMIDLIST pointer that is not stored in a Pidl variable.

member.name: M:Au.Shell.Pidl.ToHexString
member.summary: Returns string ":: HexEncodedITEMIDLIST". It can be used with some functions of this library, mostly of classes Shell, Shell.Pidl and Icons. Cannot be used with native and .NET functions. Returns null if this variable does not have an ITEMIDLIST (eg disposed or detached).

member.name: M:Au.Shell.Pidl.LibToHexString(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The same as , just uses an ITEMIDLIST pointer that is not stored in a Pidl variable.

member.name: M:Au.Shell.Run(System.String,System.String,Au.Types.SRFlags,Au.Types.SRMore)
member.summary: Runs/opens a program, document, directory (folder), URL, new email, Control Panel item etc. The returned variable contains some process info - process id etc.
member.param: What to run. Can be: Full path of a file or directory. Examples: @"C:\file.txt", Folders.System + "notepad.exe", @"%Folders.System%\notepad.exe". Filename of a file or directory, like "notepad.exe". The function calls . Path relative to . Examples: "x.exe", @"subfolder\x.exe", @".\subfolder\x.exe", @"..\another folder\x.exe". URL. Examples: "http://a.b.c/d", "file:///path". Email, like "mailto:a@b.c". Subject, body etc also can be specified, and Google knows how. Shell object's ITEMIDLIST like ":: HexEncodedITEMIDLIST". See , . Can be used to open virtual folders and items like Control Panel. Shell object's parsing name, like @"::{CLSID}". See , . Can be used to open virtual folders and items like Control Panel. To run a Windows Store App, use @"shell:AppsFolder\WinStoreAppId" format. Examples: @"shell:AppsFolder\Microsoft.WindowsCalculator_8wekyb3d8bbwe!App", @"shell:AppsFolder\windows.immersivecontrolpanel_cw5n1h2txyewy!microsoft.windows.immersivecontrolpanel". To discover the string use or Google. Supports environment variables, like @"%TMP%\file.txt". See .
Command line arguments. This function expands environment variables if starts with "%" or "\"%".
Allows to specify more parameters.
member.exception: Failed. For example, the file does not exist.
member.remarks: It works like when you double-click a file icon. It may start new process or not. For example it may just activate window if the program is already running. Uses API ShellExecuteEx. Similar to .

member.name: M:Au.Shell.TryRun(System.String,System.String,Au.Types.SRFlags,Au.Types.SRMore)
member.summary: Calls and handles exceptions. All parameters are the same. If Run throws exception, prints it as warning and returns null.
member.remarks: This is useful when you don't care whether Run succeeded and don't want to use try/catch. Handles only exception of type AuException. It is thrown when fails, usually when the file does not exist.

member.name: M:Au.Shell.RunConsole(System.String@,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Text.Encoding)
member.summary: Runs a console program, waits until its process ends, and gets its output text. Returns the process exit code. Usually a non-0 value means error.
member.param: Receives the output text. Console programs have two output text streams - standard output and standard error. This function gets both, and the error text is always after the output text.

Path or name of an .exe or .bat file. Can be: Full path. Examples: @"C:\folder\x.exe", Folders.System + "x.exe", @"%Folders.System%\x.exe". Filename, like "x.exe". The function calls . Path relative to . Examples: "x.exe", @"subfolder\x.exe", @".\subfolder\x.exe", @"..\another folder\x.exe". Supports environment variables, like @"%TMP%\x.bat". See .
Command line arguments. This function expands environment variables if starts with "%" or "\"%".
Working directory. Default - of this process.
Text encoding used to convert console's ANSI text to C# Unicode text.
member.exception: Failed, for example file not found.
member.remarks: Does not show the console window. Uses . Does not use Windows shell API. See also .

member.name: M:Au.Shell.RunConsole(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Text.Encoding)
member.summary: Runs a console program (hidden), waits until its process ends, and prints its output text. Calls and .

member.summary: Opens parent folder in Explorer and selects the file. Returns null if fails, for example if the file does not exist.
member.param: Full path of a file or directory or other shell object. Supports @"%environmentVariable%\..." (see ) and "::..." (see ).

member.name: T:Au.Path_
member.summary: Extends .

member.name: M:Au.Path_.ExpandEnvVar(System.String)
member.summary: If path starts with "%" or "\"%", expands environment variables enclosed in %, else just returns path. Also supports known folder names, like "%Folders.Documents%". More info in Remarks.
member.param: Any string. Can be null.
member.remarks:
Supports known folder names as you can get with class properties. Example: @"%Folders.Documents%\file.txt". Example: @"%Folders.Virtual.ControlPanel%" //gets ":: HexEncodedITEMIDLIST". Usually known folders are used like string path = Folders.Documents + "file.txt". It's easier and faster. However it cannot be used when you want to store paths in text files, registry, etc. Then this feature is useful. To get known folder path, this function calls .
This function is called by many functions of classes Path_, Files, Shell, Icons, some others, therefore all they support environment variables and known folders in path string.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.LibGetEnvVar(System.String)
member.summary: Gets environment variable's value. Returns "" if variable not found. Does not support Folders.X.
member.param: Case-insensitive name. Without %.
member.remarks: Environment variable values cannot be "" or null. Setting empty value removes the variable.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.LibEnvVarExists(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if environment variable exists.
member.param: Case-insensitive name.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.IsFullPath(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if the string is full path, like @"C:\a\b.txt" or @"C:" or @"\\server\share\...":
member.param: Any string. Can be null.
member.remarks:
Returns true if matches one of these wildcard patterns:
@"?:\*" - local path, like @"C:\a\b.txt". Here ? is A-Z, a-z.
@"?:" - drive name, like @"C:". Here ? is A-Z, a-z.
@"\\*" - network path, like @"\\server\share\...". Or has prefix @"\\?\".
Supports '/' characters too. Supports only file-system paths. Returns false if path is URL () or starts with "::". If path starts with "%environmentVariable%", shows warning and returns false. You should at first expand environment variables with or instead use .

member.name: M:Au.Path_.IsFullPathExpandEnvVar(System.String@)
member.summary: Expands environment variables and calls . Returns true if the string is full path, like @"C:\a\b.txt" or @"C:" or @"\\server\share\...":
member.param: Any string. Can be null. If starts with '%' character, calls with expanded environment variables (). If it returns true, replaces the passed variable with the expanded path string.
member.remarks:
Returns true if matches one of these wildcard patterns:
@"?:\*" - local path, like @"C:\a\b.txt". Here ? is A-Z, a-z.
@"?:" - drive name, like @"C:". Here ? is A-Z, a-z.
@"\\*" - network path, like @"\\server\share\...". Or has prefix @"\\?\".
Supports '/' characters too. Supports only file-system paths. Returns false if path is URL () or starts with "::".

member.name: M:Au.Path_.GetRootLength(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the length of the drive or network folder part in path, including its separator if any. If the string does not start with a drive or network folder path, returns 0 or prefix length (@"\\?\" or @"\\?\UNC\").
member.param: Full path or any string. Can be null. Should not be "%environmentVariable%\...".
member.remarks: Supports prefixes @"\\?\" and @"\\?\UNC\". Supports separators '\\' and '/'.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.GetUrlProtocolLength(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the length of the URL protocol name (also known as URI scheme) in string, including ':'. If the string does not start with a protocol name, returns 0. URL examples: "http:" (returns 5), "http://www.x.com" (returns 5), "file:///path" (returns 5), "shell:etc" (returns 6). The protocol can be unknown, the function just checks string format, which is an ASCII alpha character followed by one or more ASCII alpha-numeric, '.', '-', '+' characters, followed by ':' character.
member.param: A URL or path or any string. Can be null.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.IsUrl(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if the string starts with a URL protocol name (existing or not) and ':' character. URL examples: "http:", "http://www.x.com", "file:///path", "shell:etc". Calls and returns true if it's not 0.
member.param: A URL or path or any string. Can be null.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.Combine(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Combines two path parts using character '\\'. For example directory path and file name.
member.param: First part. Usually a directory.
Second part. Usually a filename or relative path.
s2 can be full path. If it is, ignore s1 and return s2 with expanded environment variables. If false (default), simply combines s1 and s2.
Call which may prepend @"\\?\" if the result path is very long. Default true.
member.remarks: If s1 and s2 are null or "", returns "". Else if s1 is null or "", returns s2. Else if s2 is null or "", returns s1. Similar to System.IO.Path.Combine. Main differences: does not throw exceptions; has some options. Does not expand environment variables. For it use before, or instead. Path that starts with an environment variable is considerd not full path.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.LibCombine(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Combines two path parts. Unlike , fails if some part is empty or @"\" or if s2 is @"\\". Also does not check s2 full path. If fails, throws exception or returns null (if noException).

member.name: M:Au.Path_.LibIsSepChar(System.Char)
member.summary: Returns true if character c == '\\' || c == '/'.

member.name: M:Au.Path_._EndsWithDriveWithoutSep(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns true if ends with ':' preceded by a drive letter, like "C:" or "more\C:", but not like "moreC:".
member.param: Can be null.
Use when want to check drive at a middle, not at the end. Eg returns true if s is @"C:\more" and length is 2.

member.name: M:Au.Path_._AddRemoveSep(System.String)
member.summary: Ensures that s either ends with a valid drive path (eg @"C:\" but not "C:") or does not end with '\\' or '/' (unless would become empty if removed).
member.param: Can be null.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.Normalize(System.String,System.String,Au.Types.PNFlags)
member.summary: Makes normal full path from path that can contain special substrings etc. The sequence of actions: 1. If path starts with '%' character, expands environment variables (see ). 2. If path is not full path but looks like URL, and used flag CanBeUrl, returns path. 3. If path is not full path, and defaultParentDirectory is not null/"", combines path with ExpandEnvVar(defaultParentDirectory). 4. If path is not full path, throws exception. 5. Calls API GetFullPathName. It replaces '/' with '\\', replaces multiple '\\' to single (where need), processes @"\.." etc, trims spaces, etc. 6. If no flag DoNotExpandDosPath, if looks like a DOS path (contains '~' etc), calls API GetLongPathName. It converts short DOS path to normal path, if possible, for example @"c:\progra~1" to @"c:\program files". It is slow. It converts path only if the file exists. 7. If no flag DoNotRemoveEndSeparator, removes '\\' character at the end, unless it is a drive path (eg @"C:\"). 8. Appends '\\' character if ends with a drive name (eg "C:" -> @"C:\"). 9. If no flag DoNotPrefixLongPath, calls , which adds @"\\?\" etc prefix if path is very long.
member.param: Any path.
If path is not full path, combine it with defaultParentDirectory to make full path.
member.exception: path is not full path, and is not used or does not make it full path.
member.remarks: Similar to . Main differences: this function expands environment variables, does not support relative paths, supports @"\\?\very long path", trims '\\' at the end if need, does not throw exceptions when [it thinks that] path is invalid (except when path is not full).

member.name: M:Au.Path_.LibNormalize(System.String,Au.Types.PNFlags,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Same as , but skips full-path checking. s should be full path. If not full and not null/"", combines with current directory.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.LibExpandDosPath(System.String)
member.summary: Calls API GetLongPathName. Does not check whether s contains '~' character etc. Note: the API is slow.
member.param: Can be null.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.LibIsPossiblyDos(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if pathOrFilename looks like a DOS filename or path. Examples: "abcde~12", "abcde~12.txt", @"c:\path\abcde~12.txt", "c:\abcde~12\path".
member.param: Can be null.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.LibNormalizeMinimally(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Prepares path for passing to API that support "..", DOS path etc. Calls ExpandEnvVar, _AddRemoveSep, PrefixLongPathIfNeed. Optionally throws if !IsFullPath(path).
member.exception: Not full path (only if throwIfNotFullPath is true).

member.name: M:Au.Path_.LibIsShellPath(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if starts with "::".
member.param: Can be null.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.PrefixLongPath(System.String)
member.summary: If path is full path (see ) and does not start with @"\\?\", prepends @"\\?\". If path is network path (like @"\\computer\folder\..."), makes like @"\\?\UNC\computer\folder\...".
member.param: Path. Can be null. Must not start with "%environmentVariable%", this function does not expand it. See .
member.remarks: Windows API kernel functions support extended-length paths, ie longer than 259 characters. But the path must have this prefix. Windows API shell functions don't support it.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.PrefixLongPathIfNeed(System.String)
member.summary: Calls if path is longer than (247).
member.param: Path. Can be null. Must not start with "%environmentVariable%", this function does not expand it. See .

member.name: M:Au.Path_.UnprefixLongPath(System.String)
member.summary: If path starts with @"\\?\" prefix, removes it. If path starts with @"\\?\UNC\" prefix, removes @"?\UNC\".
member.param: Path. Can be null. Must not start with "%environmentVariable%", this function does not expand it. See .

member.name: M:Au.Path_._GetPrefixLength(System.String)
member.summary: If s starts with @"\\?\UNC\", returns 8. Else if starts with @"\\?\", returns 4. Else returns 0.
member.param: Can be null.

member.name: F:Au.Path_.MaxFilePathLength
member.summary: Maximal file (not directory) path length supported by all functions (native, .NET and this library). For longer paths need @"\\?\" prefix. It is supported by most native kernel API (but not shell API) and by most functions of this library.

member.name: F:Au.Path_.MaxDirectoryPathLength
member.summary: Maximal directory path length supported by all functions (native, .NET and this library). For longer paths need @"\\?\" prefix. It is supported by most native kernel API (but not shell API) and by most functions of this library.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.CorrectFileName(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Replaces characters that cannot be used in file names. Also corrects other forms of invalid or problematic filename: trims spaces and other blank characters; replaces "." at the end; prepends "@" if a reserved name like "CON" or "CON.txt"; returns "-" if name is null/empty/whitespace. Returns valid filename. However it can be too long (itself or when combined with a directory path).
member.param: Initial filename.
A string that will replace each invalid character. Default "-".

member.name: M:Au.Path_.IsInvalidFileName(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if name cannot be used for a file name, eg contains '\\' etc characters or is empty. More info: .
member.param: Any string. Example: "name.txt". Can be null.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.GetFileName(System.String)
member.summary: Gets filename with extension. Returns "" if there is no filename. Returns null if path is null.
member.param: Path or filename. Can be null.
member.remarks:
Similar to . Some diferences: does not throw exceptions; if ends with '\\' or '/', gets part before it, eg "B" from @"C:\A\B\". Supports separators '\\' and '/'. Also supports URL and shell parsing names like @"::{CLSID-1}\0\::{CLSID-2}". Example paths and results:
@"C:\A\B\file.txt" -> "file.txt". "file.txt" -> "file.txt". "file" -> "file". @"C:\A\B" -> "B". @"C:\A\B\" -> "B". @"C:\A\/B\/" -> "B". @"C:\" -> "". @"C:" -> "". @"\\network\share" -> "share". @"C:\aa\file.txt:alt.stream" -> "file.txt:alt.stream". "http://a.b.c" -> "a.b.c". "::{A}\::{B}" -> "::{B}". "" -> "". null -> null.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.GetFileNameWithoutExtension(System.String)
member.summary: Gets filename without extension. Returns "" if there is no filename. Returns null if path is null.
member.param: Path or filename. Can be null.
member.remarks:
Similar to Some diferences: does not throw exceptions; if ends with '\\' or '/', gets part before it, eg "B" from @"C:\A\B\" (then does not remove extension from it because it is a directory name). Supports separators '\\' and '/'. Also supports URL and shell parsing names like @"::{CLSID-1}\0\::{CLSID-2}". Example paths and results:
@"C:\A\B\file.txt" -> "file". "file.txt" -> "file". "file" -> "file". @"C:\A\B" -> "B". @"C:\A\B\" -> "B". @"C:\A\B.B\" -> "B.B". @"C:\" -> "". @"C:" -> "". @"\\network\share" -> "share". @"C:\aa\file.txt:alt.stream" -> "file.txt:alt". "http://a.b.c" -> "a.b". "::{A}\::{B}" -> "::{B}". "" -> "". null -> null.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.GetExtension(System.String)
member.summary: Gets filename extension, like ".txt". Returns "" if there is no extension. Returns null if path is null.
member.param: Path or filename. Can be null.
member.remarks: Supports separators '\\' and '/'. Like , but does not throw exceptions.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.GetExtension(System.String,System.String@)
member.summary: Gets filename extension and path part without the extension. More info: .
member.param: Path or filename. Can be null.
Receives path part without the extension. Can be the same variable as path.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.FindExtension(System.String)
member.summary: Finds filename extension, like ".txt". Returns '.' character index, or -1 if there is no extension.
member.param: Path or filename. Can be null.
member.remarks: Returns -1 if '.' is before '\\' or '/'.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.GetDirectoryPath(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Removes filename part from path. By default also removes separator ('\\' or '/') if it is not after drive name (eg "C:"). Returns "" if the string is a filename. Returns null if the string is null or a root (like @"C:\" or "C:" or @"\\server\share" or "http:").
member.param: Path or filename. Can be null.
Don't remove the separator character(s) ('\\' or '/'). Examples: from @"C:\A\B" gets @"C:\A\", not @"C:\A"; from "http://x.y" gets "http://", not "http:".
member.remarks:
Similar to . Some diferences: does not throw exceptions; skips '\\' or '/' at the end (eg from @"C:\A\B\" gets @"C:\A", not @"C:\A\B"); does not expand DOS path; much faster. Parses raw string. You may want to it at first. Supports separators '\\' and '/'. Also supports URL and shell parsing names like @"::{CLSID-1}\0\::{CLSID-2}". Example paths and results (withSeparator=false):
@"C:\A\B\file.txt" -> @"C:\A\B". "file.txt" -> "". @"C:\A\B\" -> @"C:\A". @"C:\A\/B\/" -> @"C:\A". @"C:\" -> null. @"\\network\share" -> null. "http:" -> null. @"C:\aa\file.txt:alt.stream" -> "C:\aa". "http://a.b.c" -> "http:". "::{A}\::{B}" -> "::{A}". "" -> "". null -> null.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.LibIsExtension(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if s is like ".ext" and the ext part does not contain characters ".\\/:".
member.param: Can be null.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.LibIsProtocol(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if s is like "protocol:" and not like "c:" or "protocol:more".
member.param: Can be null.

member.name: M:Au.Path_.MakeUnique(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets path with unique filename for a new file or directory. If the specified path is of an existing file or directory, returns path where the filename part is modified like "file 2.txt", "file 3.txt" etc. Else returns unchanged path.
member.param: Suggested full path.
The path is for a directory. The number is always appended at the very end, not before .extension.

member.name: T:Au.NamespaceDoc

member.name: T:Au.Folders
member.summary: Gets known/special folder paths (Desktop, Temp, etc).
member.remarks:
For return values is used type , not string. It is implicitly convertible to string. Its operator + appends a filename or relative path string, with @"\" separator if need. Example: string s = Folders.Desktop + "file.txt"; //C:\Users\Name\Desktop\file.txt If a function cannot get folder path, the return value contains null string. Then the + operator would throw AuException.
Some folders are known only on newer Windows versions or only on some computers. Some property-get functions have a suffix like "_Win8" which means that the folder is unavailable on older Windows. Some known folders, although supported and registerd, may be still not created.
Some folders are virtual, for example Control Panel. They don't have a file system path, but can be identified by an unmanaged array called "ITEMIDLIST" or "PIDL". Functions of the nested class return it as . Functions of the nested class return it as string ":: HexEncodedITEMIDLIST" that can be used with some functions of this library (of classes Shell, Shell.Pidl, Icons) but not with .NET or native functions.
Most functions use Windows "Known Folders" API, such as SHGetKnownFolderPath. The list of Windows predefined known folders: KNOWNFOLDERID. Names of folders specific to this application have "This" prefix, like ThisApp.
Some paths depend on the bitness (32 or 64 bit) of the OS and this process. The example paths below are for English versions of Windows on most computers.
32-bit Windows
System, SystemX86, SystemX64: @"C:\WINDOWS\system32" ProgramFiles, ProgramFilesX86, ProgramFilesX64: @"C:\Program Files" ProgramFilesCommon, ProgramFilesCommonX86, ProgramFilesCommonX64: @"C:\Program Files\Common Files"
64-bit Windows, 64-bit process
System, SystemX64: @"C:\WINDOWS\system32" SystemX86: @"C:\WINDOWS\SysWOW64" ProgramFiles, ProgramFilesX64: @"C:\Program Files" ProgramFilesX86: @"C:\Program Files (x86)" ProgramFilesCommon, ProgramFilesCommonX64: @"C:\Program Files\Common Files" ProgramFilesCommonX86: @"C:\Program Files (x86)\Common Files"
64-bit Windows, 32-bit process
System: @"C:\WINDOWS\system32". However the OS in most cases redirects this path to @"C:\WINDOWS\SysWOW64". SystemX86: @"C:\WINDOWS\SysWOW64" SystemX64: @"C:\WINDOWS\Sysnative". The OS redirects it to the true @"C:\WINDOWS\system32". It is a special path that you don't see in Explorer. ProgramFiles, ProgramFilesX86: @"C:\Program Files (x86)" ProgramFilesX64: @"C:\Program Files" ProgramFilesCommon, ProgramFilesCommonX86: @"C:\Program Files (x86)\Common Files" ProgramFilesCommonX64: @"C:\Program Files\Common Files"

member.summary: Temp folder (temporary files) of this user account.

member.name: P:Au.Folders.ThisApp
member.summary: Folder containing assemblies of this appdomain. Calls .
member.remarks: Unlike , this path can be different for each appdomain; it is set when creating the AppDomain. See also , it gets full path (with file name) of appdomain's entry assembly.

member.name: P:Au.Folders.ThisAppTemp
member.summary: Gets or sets path of the temporary files folder of this application. Default is Folders.Temp + Application.ProductName. The 'set' function does not change system settings, it just remembers a string that will be later returned by the 'get' function in this appdomain. The 'get' function creates the folder if does not exist.

member.name: P:Au.Folders.ThisAppDocuments
member.summary: Gets or sets path of user document files folder of this application. Default is Folders.Documents + Application.ProductName. The 'set' function does not change system settings, it just remembers a string that will be later returned by the 'get' function in this appdomain. The 'get' function creates the folder if does not exist.

member.name: P:Au.Folders.ThisAppData
member.summary: Gets or sets path of private files folder of this application on this user account. Default is Folders.RoamingAppData + Application.ProductName. The 'set' function does not change system settings, it just remembers a string that will be later returned by the 'get' function in this appdomain. The 'get' function creates the folder if does not exist.

member.name: P:Au.Folders.ThisAppDataLocal
member.summary: Gets or sets path of local (non-roaming) private files folder of this application on this user account. Default is Folders.LocalAppData + Application.ProductName. The 'set' function does not change system settings, it just remembers a string that will be later returned by the 'get' function in this appdomain. The 'get' function creates the folder if does not exist.

member.name: P:Au.Folders.ThisAppDataCommon
member.summary: Gets or sets path of common (all users) private files folder of this application. Default is Folders.ProgramData + Application.ProductName. The 'set' function does not change system settings, it just remembers a string that will be later returned by the 'get' function in this appdomain. Note: the ProgramData folder has special permissions. Programs running not as administrator usually cannot write there. This function does not auto-create the folder; usually it is created when installing the application.

member.name: P:Au.Folders.ThisProcess
member.summary: Folder containing the program file of this process. Calls . Unlike , this path is the same for all app domains of this process.

member.name: P:Au.Folders.ThisAppImages
member.summary: Gets or sets path of images (icons etc) folder of this application. Default is ThisApp + "Images". Functions of these classes will look for image there: Icons, AuMenu, AuToolbar, WinImage, possibly some other.

member.name: P:Au.Folders.SystemX64
member.summary: Gets non-redirected path of the System32 folder.
member.remarks: If this process is 32-bit and OS is 64-bit, when it uses the folder path (@"C:\WINDOWS\system32"), the OS in most cases redirects it to @"C:\Windows\SysWOW64", which contains 32-bit versions of program files. Use SystemX64 when you want to avoid the redirection and access the true System32 folder which on 64-bit OS contains 64-bit program files. More info in class help.

member.name: M:Au.Mouse.Move(Au.Types.POINT)
member.summary: Moves the cursor (mouse pointer) to the specified position in screen.
member.param: Coordinates relative to the primary screen. Tip: When need coordinates relative to another screen or/and the work area, use or tuple (x, y, workArea) etc. Example: Mouse.Move((x, y, true));.
member.exception: The specified x y is not in screen. No exception if option Relaxed is true (then moves to a screen edge).

Failed to move the cursor to the specified x y. Some reasons: 1. Another thread blocks or modifies mouse input (API BlockInput, mouse hooks, frequent API SendInput etc); 2. The active window belongs to a process of higher UAC integrity level; 3. Some application called API ClipCursor. No exception if option Relaxed is true (then final cursor position is undefined).
member.remarks: Uses : , , .

Failed to move the cursor to the calculated x y. Some reasons: 1. Another thread blocks or modifies mouse input (API BlockInput, mouse hooks, frequent API SendInput etc); 2. The active window belongs to a process of higher UAC integrity level; 3. Some application called API ClipCursor. No exception option Relaxed is true (then final cursor position is undefined).
member.remarks: Uses : , , .

member.name: M:Au.Mouse.ClickEx(Au.Types.MButton,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Clicks, double-clicks, presses or releases a mouse button. By default does not move the mouse cursor.
member.param: Button and action. Default: left click.

Use . It is the mouse cursor position set by the most recent 'mouse move' or 'mouse move and click' function called in this thread. Use this option for reliability. Example: Mouse.Move(100, 100); Mouse.ClickEx(..., true);. The click is always at 100 100, even if somebody changes cursor position between Mouse.Move sets it and Mouse.ClickEx uses it. In such case this option atomically moves the cursor to LastMoveXY. This movement is instant and does not use . If false (default), clicks at the current cursor position (does not move it).
member.exception: Invalid button flags (multiple buttons or actions specified).
member.remarks: Uses : , .

Where to write the data. Can be any valid memory of specified size, for example a struct address.
resultBuffer memory size. Note: this function will damage process memory if using bad resultBuffer or bufferSize.
0 or index of first character of hex-encoded substring in s.
member.remarks: Skips spaces and other non-hex-digit characters. Example: "01 23 46 67" is the same as "01234667". The number of hex-digit characters should be divisible by 2, else the last character is ignored.

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.Base64Decode(System.String)
member.summary: Converts Base64 string to binary data (bytes). Returns byte[] containing the data.
member.param: Base64 string. Can be null, then returns null.
member.remarks:
How this function is different than : 1. Allows (discards) non-base64 characters. 2. Supports URL-safe characters: '-' for '+' and '_' for '/'. 3. No exception when string length is not multiple of 4, eg if does not contain '=' characters for padding.
This library does not have Base64-encode functions. Use .

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.GuidToBase64Filename(System.Guid)
member.summary: Converts GUID to string that can be used in file paths and URLs.
member.remarks: Standard Base64 strings cannot be used in file paths and URLs, because can contain characters '/' and '+'. This function replaces them with '_' and '-'. Also trims "==" at the end. Such string can be parsed with Convert_ class functions, not with Convert class functions.

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.Utf8LengthFromString(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the number of bytes that would by produced by converting C# string to UTF8, not including the terminating '\0' character.
member.param: C# string (UTF16). Can be null.

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.Utf8FromString(System.String,System.Byte*,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts C# string to '\0'-terminated UTF8 string. Stores the UTF8 string in caller's buffer. Returns UTF8 string length in bytes, not including the terminating '\0' character. If fails (unlikely if passed correct arguments), returns 0 and sets buffer="".
member.param: C# string (UTF16). Can be null.
Caller-allocated memory of bufLen length.
buffer length in bytes. Should be at least +1, else converts only part of string. The maximal possible required buffer length for whole string can be s.Length*3+1.
member.remarks: Calls API WideCharToMultiByte. This is the most low-level and therefore fastest overload. Does not allocate any memory. With big strings much faster than .NET Encoding class functions. Use buffer/bufLen carefully. If bufLen is greater that the memory buffer length, other memory will be overwritten/damaged.

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.Utf8FromString(System.String)
member.summary: Converts C# string to '\0'-terminated UTF8 string.
member.param: C# string (UTF16). If null, returns null.
member.remarks: How this is different from .NET Encoding class functions: 1. Uses WideCharToMultiByte. 2. Faster with big strings. 3. The returned string is '\0'-terminated. 4. No exceptions (unless the string is so large that fails to allocate so much memory).

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.LibUtf8FromString(System.String,System.WeakReference{System.Byte[]}@,System.Int32*,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts C# string to '\0'-terminated UTF8 string managed by a WeakReference variable.

member.name: M:Au.Convert_.Utf8ToString(System.Byte*,System.Int32)

member.param: UTF8 string. If null, returns null.
Length of utf8 or part of it. If negative, the function finds utf8 length; then utf8 must be '\0'-terminated.
member.remarks: Uses API MultiByteToWideChar. There is no overload that takes byte[], because for it can be used .NET Encoding class functions. The speed is similar; this is slower with short strings but faster with long strings.

member.name: T:Au.Debug_
member.summary: Functions useful to debug code.
member.remarks: The Debug_.PrintX functions write to the same output as , not to the trace listeners like etc do. Also they add caller's name, file and line number. Functions Print, PrintIf, PrintFunc and Dialog work only if DEBUG is defined, which normally is when the caller project is in Debug configuration. Else they are not called, and arguments not evaluated at run time. This is because they have [("DEBUG")]. Note: when used in a library, the above functions depend on DEBUG of the library project and not on DEBUG of the consumer project of the library. For example, the library may be in Release configuration even if its consumer project is in Debug configuration. If your library wants to show some info only if its consumer project is in Debug config, instead you can use code like if(Opt.Debug.Verbose) PrintWarning("text");; see , Opt.Debug..

member.name: P:Au.Debug_.TextPrefix
member.summary: Prefix for Debug_.Print, Debug_.PrintIf. Default is "Debug: ".
member.example:
Blue text.
Debug_.TextPrefix = "<><c 0xff0000>"; Debug_.TextSuffix = "</c>";

member.name: P:Au.Debug_.TextSuffix
member.summary: Suffix for Debug_.Print, Debug_.PrintIf.

Offset in the memory allocated by the constructor.
Find true string length by searching for '\0' character in nChars range. If false, the returned string is of nChars length even if contains '\0' characters.

member.name: T:Au.Process_.UacInfo
member.summary: Holds an access token (security info) of a process and provides various security info, eg UAC integrity level.

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.UnsafeTokenHandle
member.summary: The access token handle.
member.remarks: The handle is managed by this variable and will be closed when disposing or GC-collecting it. Use where need.

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.Failed
member.summary: Returns true if the last called property function failed. Normally it should never fail. Only can fail (then it returns null).

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.Elevation
member.summary: Gets the UAC elevation type of the process. Elevation types: Full - runs as administrator (High or System integrity level). Limited - runs as standard user (Medium, Medium+UIAccess or Low integrity level) on administrator user session. Default - all processes in this user session run as admin, or all as standard user. Can be: non-administrator user session; service session; UAC is turned off. Unknown - failed to get. Normally it never happens; only can fail (then it returns null). This property is rarely useful. Instead use other properties of this class.

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.IsUIAccess
member.summary: Returns true if the process has uiAccess property. A uiAccess process can access/automate all windows of processes running in the same user session. Most processes don't have this property. They cannot access/automate windows of higher integrity level (High, System, uiAccess) processes and Windows 8 store apps. For example, cannot send keys and Windows messages. Note: High IL (admin) processes also can have this property, therefore IsUIAccess is not the same as IntegrityLevelAndUIAccess==IL.UIAccess ( returns UIAccess only for Medium+uiAccess processes; for High+uiAccess processes it returns High). Some Windows API work slightly differently with uiAccess and non-uiAccess admin processes. This property is rarely useful. Instead use other properties of this class.

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.IntegrityLevel
member.summary: Gets the UAC integrity level (IL) of the process. IL from lowest to highest value: Untrusted - the most limited rights. Very rare. Low - very limited rights. Used by Internet Explorer tab processes, Windows Store apps. Medium - limited rights. Most processes (unless UAC turned off). UIAccess - Medium IL + can access/automate High IL windows (user interface). Note: Only the property can return UIAccess. This property returns High instead (the same as in Process Explorer). High - most rights. Processes that run as administrator. System - almost all rights. Services, some system processes. Protected - undocumented. Rare. Unknown - failed to get IL. Unlikely. The IL enum member values can be used like if(x.IntegrityLevel > IL.Medium) ... . If UAC is turned off, most non-service processes on administrator account have High IL; on non-administrator - Medium.

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.IntegrityLevelAndUIAccess
member.summary: The same as , but can return UIAccess.

member.name: M:Au.Process_.UacInfo.GetOfProcess(System.Int32)
member.summary: Opens process access token and creates/returns new variable that holds it. Then you can use its properties. Returns null if failed. For example fails for services and some other processes if current process is not administrator. To get UacInfo of this process, instead use .
member.param: Process id. If you have a window, use .

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.ThisProcess
member.summary: Gets variable for this process.

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.IsAdmin
member.summary: Returns true if this process is running as administrator, ie if the user belongs to the local Administrators group and the process is not limited by UAC. This function for example can be used to check whether you can write to protected locations in the file system and registry.

member.name: P:Au.Process_.UacInfo.IsUacDisabled
member.summary: Returns true if UAC is disabled (turned off) on this Windows 7 computer. On Windows 8 and 10 UAC cannot be disabled, although you can disable UAC elevation consent dialogs.

member.remarks: Calls , therefore the dialog is already open when this function returns. More info:

member.name: P:Au.AuDialog.Result
member.summary: Gets selected button id and other results packed in a DResult variable. It is the same variable as the ShowDialog return value. If the result is still unavailable (eg the dialog still not closed): If called from the same thread that called ShowDialog, returns null. If called from another thread, waits until the dialog is closed and the return value is available. Note that ShowDialogNoWait calls ShowDialog in another thread.

member.name: M:Au.AuDialog.ThreadWaitForOpen
member.summary: Can be used by other threads to wait until the dialog is open. If returns true, the dialog is open and you can send messages to it. If returns false, the dialog is already closed or failed to show.

member.name: M:Au.AuDialog.ThreadWaitForClosed
member.summary: Can be used by other threads to wait until the dialog is closed.

member.name: P:Au.AuDialog.IsOpen
member.summary: Returns true if the dialog is open and your code can send messages to it.

member.name: P:Au.AuDialog.DialogWindow
member.summary: Gets dialog window handle as Wnd. Returns default(Wnd) if the dialog is not open.

member.name: P:Au.AuDialog.Send
member.summary: Allows to modify dialog controls while it is open, and close the dialog.
member.remarks:
Example: d.Send.Close(); . Example: d.Send.ChangeText2("new text", false); . Example: d.Send.Message(TDApi.TDM.CLICK_VERIFICATION, 1); .
Can be used only while the dialog is open. Before showing the dialog returns null. After closing the dialog the returned variable is deactivated; its method calls are ignored. Can be used in dialog event handlers. Also can be used in another thread, for example with and .

Text below main instruction.
See . Examples: "OK|Cancel", "1 OK|2 Cancel|5 Save|4 Don't Save".
Owner window or null. See .
Text that the user can show and hide.
Text at the bottom of the dialog. Icon can be specified like "i|Text", where i is: x error, ! warning, i info, v shield, a app.
Title bar text. If omitted, null or "", uses .
Adds radio buttons. A list of strings "id text" separated by |, like "1 One|2 Two|3 Three".
If not null/"", shows a check box with this text. To make it checked, append "|true", "|check" or "|checked".
id of button that responds to the Enter key.

Y position in . If default - screen center. You also can use etc.
If not 0, auto-close the dialog after this time (seconds) and set result's Button property = .
member.remarks: The returned variable has these properties: selected button id, selected radio button id, check box state. Tip: DResult supports implicit cast to int. You can use code switch(AuDialog.ShowEx(...)) instead of switch(AuDialog.ShowEx(...).Button) . Tip: Use named arguments. Example: AuDialog.ShowEx("Text.", icon: DIcon.Info, title: "Title") . This function allows you to use most of the dialog features, but not all. Alternatively you can create a AuDialog class instance, set properties and call ShowDialog. Example in class help.

member.name: M:Au.AuDialog.Show(System.String,System.String,System.String,Au.Types.DIcon,Au.Types.DFlags,Au.Types.AnyWnd,System.String)
member.summary: Shows dialog. Returns selected button id.
member.param: Main instruction. Bigger font.
Text below main instruction.

Button ids and labels, like "1 OK|2 Cancel|5 Save|4 Don't Save". Missing ids are auto-generated, for example "OK|Cancel|100 Custom1|Custom2" is the same as "1 OK|2 Cancel|100 Custom1|101 Custom2". The first in the list button is default, ie responds to the Enter key. For example, "2 No|1 Yes" adds Yes and No buttons and makes No default. Trims newlines around ids and labels. For example, "
1 One
|
2
Two

" is the same as "1 One|2 Two".
To create keyboard shortcuts, use & character in custom button labels. Use && for literal &. Example: "1 &Tuesday[]2 T&hursday[]3 Saturday && Sunday".
There are 6 common buttons: OK, Yes, No, Retry, Cancel, Close. Buttons that have other labels are custom buttons. How common buttons are different: 1. DFlags.CommandLinks does not change their style. 2. They have keyboard shortcuts that cannot be changed. Inserting & in a label makes it a custom button. 3. Button Cancel can be selected with the Esc key. It also adds X (Close) button in title bar, which selects Cancel. 4. Always displayed in standard order (eg Yes No, never No Yes). But you can for example use "2 No|1 Yes" to set default button = No. 5. The displayed button label is localized, ie different when the Windows UI language is not English.
If omitted, null or "", the dialog will have OK button, id 1. You can use in flags to change the style of custom buttons. See also: .
Owner window or null. See .
Text that the user can show and hide.
member.remarks: Calls . Tip: Use named arguments. Example: AuDialog.Show("Text.", icon: DIcon.Info) .

member.name: T:Au.CsvTable
member.summary: Parses and composes CSV text. Stores CSV table data in memory as a List of string arrays.
member.remarks: CSV is a text format used to store a single table of data in human-readable/editable way. It is a list of lines (called rows or records) containing one or more values (called fields or cells) separated by a separator character. There is no strictly defined CSV standard. CsvTable uses these rules: Fields containg characters (default ','), characters (default '"') and multiple lines must be enclosed in characters. Example: "ab, cd". Each Quote character in such fields must be escaped (replaced) with two characters. Example: "ab ""cd"" ef". Fields that start or end with ASCII space or tab characters must be enclosed in characters, unless is false. Example: " ab ". Rows in CSV text can have different field count.

member.name: M:Au.CsvTable.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance and parses CSV text, the same as .
member.param: CSV text.
member.exception: Invalid CSV, eg contains incorrectly enclosed fields.
member.remarks: Uses default , and values (',', '"', true).

member.name: P:Au.CsvTable.Data
member.summary: Gets the internal List containing rows as string arrays.
member.remarks: It's not a copy; changing it will change the data of this variable. You can do anything with the List. For example, sort it, find rows containing certain field values, get/set field values directly, add/remove rows directly. All row arrays have Length equal to , and it must remain so; you can change Length, but then need to call ColumnCount=newLength.

example.code: x.Data.Sort((a,b) => string.CompareOrdinal(a[0], b[0]));

member.name: P:Au.CsvTable.Separator
member.summary: Sets or gets the field separator character used when parsing and composing CSV text. Initially it is ','.

member.name: P:Au.CsvTable.Quote
member.summary: Sets or gets the quote character used when parsing and composing CSV text. Initially it is '"'.

member.name: P:Au.CsvTable.TrimSpaces
member.summary: Whether to ignore ASCII space and tab characters at the beginning and end of fields when parsing CSV. Initially true.

member.summary: Parses CSV text and stores all data in internal List of string arrays.
member.param: CSV text. If rows in CSV text have different field count, the longest row sets the property and all row array lenghts; array elements of missing CSV fields will be null.
member.exception: Invalid CSV, eg contains incorrectly enclosed fields.
member.remarks: Depends on these properties: (initially ','), (initially '"'), (initially true).

member.name: M:Au.CsvTable.ToString
member.summary: Composes CSV text from the internal List of string arrays.
member.remarks: Depends on these properties: (initially ','), (initially '"').

member.name: P:Au.CsvTable.RowCount
member.summary: Gets or sets row count. The 'get' function returns the Count property of the internal List of string arrays. The 'set' function can add new rows or remove rows at the end.

member.name: P:Au.CsvTable.ColumnCount
member.summary: Gets or sets column count. The 'get' function returns the length of all string arrays in the internal List. The 'set' function can add new columns or remove columns at the right.

member.param: 0-based row index. With the 'set' function it can be negative or equal to ; then adds new row.
0-based column index. With the 'set' function it can be >= and < 1000; then sets ColumnCount = column + 1.

member.remarks: The 'get' function gets the row array. It's not a copy; changing its elements will change the data of this variable. The 'set' function sets the row array. Does not copy the array, unless its Length is less than .

member.name: T:Au.Wnd
member.summary: A variable of Wnd type represents a window or control. It is a window handle, also known as HWND.
member.remarks:
Wnd functions can be used with windows and controls of any process/thread. Also can be used with .NET form/control and WPF window class variables, like Wnd w=(Wnd)form; w.Method(...); or ((Wnd)form).Method(...);.
There are two main types of windows - top-level windows and controls. Controls are child windows of top-level windows.
More functions are in the nested classes - , etc. They are used mostly in programming, rarely in automation scripts.
What happens when a Wnd function fails:
Functions that get window properties don't throw exceptions. They return false/0/null/empty. Most of them support , and it is mentioned in function documentation.
Many functions that change window properties throw exception. Exceptions are listed in function documentation. Almost all these functions throw only .
Other functions that change window properties return false. They are more often used in programming than in automation scripts.
When a 'find' function does not find the window or control, it returns default(Wnd) (window handle 0). Then will return true.
If a function does not follow these rules, it is mentioned in function documentation.
Many functions fail if the window's process has a higher UAC integrity level (aministrator, uiAccess) than this process, unless this process has uiAccess level. Especially the functions that change window properties. Some functions that still work: Activate, ActivateLL, ShowMinimized, ShowNotMinimized, ShowNotMinMax, Close.
The Wnd type can be used with native Windows API functions without casting. Use Wnd for the parameter type in the declaration, like [DllImport(...)] static extern bool NativeFunction(Wnd hWnd, ...).
See also: MSDN article Window Features.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Wait(System.Double,System.Boolean,System.String,System.String,Au.Types.WFEtc,Au.Types.WFFlags,System.Func{Au.Wnd,System.Boolean},System.Object)
member.summary: Waits until window exists, is visible (optionally) and active (optionally). Returns window handle. On timeout returns default(Wnd) if is negative; else exception. Parameters etc are the same as .
member.param: The maximal time to wait, seconds. If 0, waits infinitely. If >0, after that time interval throws . If <0, after that time interval returns default(Wnd).
The window must be the active window (), and not minimized.
member.remarks: By default ignores invisible windows. Use flag if need. If you have a window's Wnd variable, to wait until it is active/visible/etc use instead.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.WaitAny(System.Double,System.Boolean,Au.Wnd.Finder[])
member.summary: Waits until any of specified windows exists, is visible (optionally) and active (optionally). Returns window handle. On timeout returns default(Wnd) if is negative; else exception.
member.param: The window must be the active window (), and not minimized.
One or more variables containing window properties.
member.remarks: By default ignores invisible windows. Use flag if need.

example.code: Wnd w = Wnd.WaitAny(10, true, new Wnd.Finder("* Notepad"), new Wnd.Finder("* Word")); Print(w);

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.WaitNot(System.Double,System.String,System.String,Au.Types.WFEtc,Au.Types.WFFlags,System.Func{Au.Wnd,System.Boolean},System.Object)
member.summary: Waits until window does not exist. Parameters etc are the same as .
member.remarks: By default ignores invisible windows. Use flag if need. If you have a window's Wnd variable, to wait until it is closed use instead. Examples: .

member.summary: Waits until window does not exist.

On timeout receives the found window.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.WaitForCondition(System.Double,System.Func{Au.Wnd,System.Boolean},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Waits for an user-defined state/condition of this window. For example active, visible, enabled, closed, contains control.
member.param: Callback function (eg lambda). It is called repeatedly, until returns true.

Do not throw exception when the window handle is invalid or the window was closed while waiting. In such case the callback function must return false, like in the examples with . Else exception is thrown (with a small delay) to prevent infinite waiting.
member.exception: The window handle is invalid or the window was closed while waiting.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.WaitForName(System.Double,System.String)
member.summary: Waits until this window has the specified name.
member.param: Window name. Usually it is the title bar text. String format: wildcard expression.
member.exception: The window handle is invalid or the window was closed while waiting.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.WaitForClosed(System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Waits until this window is closed/destroyed or until its process ends.
member.param: Wait until the process of this window ends.
member.exception: Failed to open process handle when is true.
member.remarks: If the window is already closed, immediately returns true.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.WaitForAnActiveWindow
member.summary: Waits while there is no active window. It sometimes happens after closing, minimizing or switching the active window, briefly until another window becomes active. Waits max 500 ms, then returns false if there is no active window. Processes Windows messages that are in the message queue of this thread. Don't need to call this after calling functions of this library.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.EnableActivate
member.summary: Temporarily enables this process to activate windows with API SetForegroundWindow. Returns false if fails (unlikely). In some cases you may need this function because Windows often disables SetForegroundWindow to not allow applications to activate their windows while the user is working (using keyboard/mouse) with the currently active window. Then SetForegroundWindow just makes the window's taskbar button flash which indicates that the windows wants attention. More info: SetForegroundWindow. Usually you don't call SetForegroundWindow directly. It is called by some other functions, for example Form.Show. Don't need to call this function before calling Wnd.Activate and other functions of this library that activate windows.

member.name: T:Au.Wnd.Misc.TaskbarButton

member.name: T:Au.Wnd.Misc.WinFormsControlNames
member.summary: Gets programming names of .NET Windows Forms controls.
member.remarks: Usually each control has a unique name. It is useful to identify controls without a classic name/text. The control id of these controls is not useful, it is not constant.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.WinFormsControlNames.#ctor(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Prepares to get control names.
member.param: Any top-level or child window of that process.
member.exception: Failed to allocate process memory (see ) needed to get control names, usually because of UAC.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.WinFormsControlNames.GetControlName(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Gets control name. Returns null if fails or the name is empty.
member.param: The control. Can be a top-level window too. Must be of the same process as the window specified in the constructor.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.WinFormsControlNames.IsWinFormsControl(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Returns true if window class name starts with "WindowsForms". Usually it means that we can get Windows Forms control name of w and its child controls.
member.param: The window. Can be top-level or control.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.WinFormsControlNames.GetSingleControlName(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Gets the programming name of a Windows Forms control. Returns null if it is not a Windows Forms control or if fails.
member.param: The control. Can be top-level window too.
member.remarks: This function is easy to use and does not throw excaptions. However, when you need names of multiple controls of a single window, better create a WinFormsControlNames instance (once) and for each control call its GetControlNameOrText method, it will be faster.

member.name: T:Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow
member.summary: Creates window and allows your derived class to replace its window procedure.
member.remarks: Similar to , but more lightweight and does not change the class name. Can register a new window class or extend (subclass) an existing class.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.Handle
member.summary: Native window handle.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.Create(System.String,System.String,Au.Types.Native.WS,Au.Types.Native.WS_EX,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Au.Wnd,Au.Types.LPARAM)
member.summary: Creates window. Calls API CreateWindowEx. Returns false if failed, for example className is not registered.
member.param: The name of any window class existing in this process. You can register a class with or use any other class.
Window name or null.
Owner or parent window, or default.
Control id or 0.
member.remarks: Your derived class should override , which calls the window procedure of window class . The window will be destroyed in these cases: 1. Called . 2. Closed by the user or some program/script. 3. When this thread ends. 4. This function called again (then destroys old window and creates new).

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.CreateMessageWindow(System.String)
member.summary: Creates message-only window. Styles: WS_POPUP, WS_EX_NOACTIVATE. More info: .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.Destroy
member.summary: Destroys the window. Calls API DestroyWindow. Does nothing if the window is already destroyed, for example closed by the user. If the window is not destroyed explicitly, the system destroys it when its thread ends.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.WndProc(Au.Wnd,System.Int32,Au.Types.LPARAM,Au.Types.LPARAM)
member.summary: Calls the window procedure of the window class (see ) and manages the lifetime of this variable. Your derived class should override this function, call base.WndProc and return its return value, except when don't need default processing. More info: Window Procedures.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.RegisterClass(System.String,Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.WndClassEx)
member.summary: Registers new window class. Returns class atom.
member.param: Class name.

Can be used to specify more fields of WNDCLASSEX that is passed to RegisterClassEx. Defaults: hCursor = arrow; hbrBackground = COLOR_BTNFACE+1; style = CS_GLOBALCLASS; others = 0/null/default. This function also adds CS_GLOBALCLASS style.
member.exception: Failed, for example if the class already exists and was registered not with this function.
member.remarks: Calls API RegisterClassEx. The class then can be used in all appdomains of this process. To create windows, use . Each class derived from MyWindow provides its own window procedure (overrides ). Windows created not with use API DefWindowProc as window procedure, and therefore are not useful. The window class remains registered until this process ends. Don't need to unregister. This function can be called multiple times for the same class, for example called once in each appdomain. Next time it just returns class atom. Thread-safe. Don't use code like static ushort _atom = Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.RegisterClass("MyClass");, because in Release configuration compiler removes this code if _atom is not used. Instead you can call this function in a static constructor.

member.name: T:Au.Wnd.Misc.MyWindow.WndClassEx
member.summary: Used with .

member.param: Name. Use null to match any. Full, case-insensitive. Wildcard etc not supported.
Class name. Use null to match any. Cannot be "". Full, case-insensitive. Wildcard etc not supported.
If used, starts searching from the next window in the Z order.

An integer identifier of the string, to store in COPYDATASTRUCT.dwData.
String containing data of any format. Can have '\0' characters.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Misc.InterProcessGetData(Au.Types.LPARAM,System.Int32@)

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.Is0
member.summary: Returns true if the window handle is 0.

example.code: Wnd w = Wnd.Find("Window*"); if(w.Is0) { Print("window not found"); return; }

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsAlive
member.summary: Returns true if the window handle identifies an existing window. Returns false if the handle is 0 or invalid. Invalid non-0 handle usually means that the window is closed/destroyed.
member.remarks: Calls and API IsWindow. Although a Wnd variable holds a window handle, which is like a reference to a window, it does not prevent closing that window and making the handle invalid. After closing the window, the OS can even assign the same handle value to a new window, although normally it can happen only after long time. Use this carefully with windows of other applications or threads. The window can be closed at any moment, even when your thread is still in this function.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsVisible
member.summary: Returns true if the window is visible. Returns false if is invisible or is a child of invisible parent. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports .
member.remarks:
Calls API IsWindowVisible. Does not call .
Even when this function returns true, the window may be actually invisible. It can be cloaked, on an inactive Windows 10 virtual desktop (cloaked), inactive Windows Store app (cloaked), transparent, zero-size, minimized, off-screen, covered by other windows or can have zero-size window region.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsVisibleEx
member.summary: Returns true if the window is visible. Returns false if is invisible or is a child of invisible parent. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports .
member.remarks:
Returns false if API IsWindowVisible returns false. Also returns false if returns true, but only for some popup windows that usually are useless and could cause problems if considered visible. Else returns true.
Even when this function returns true, the window may be actually invisible. It can be cloaked (excepth the above case), on an inactive Windows 10 virtual desktop (cloaked), inactive Windows Store app (cloaked), transparent, zero-size, minimized, off-screen, covered by other windows or can have zero-size window region.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsVisibleAndNotCloaked
member.summary: Returns true if returns true and returns false.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Show(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Shows (if hidden) or hides this window. Does not activate/deactivate/zorder. With windows of current thread usually it's better to use .
member.remarks: Calls API ShowWindow with SW_SHOWNA or SW_HIDE.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ShowLL(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Shows (if hidden) or hides this window. Does not activate/deactivate/zorder.
member.remarks:
This library has two similar functions - and ShowLL. Show is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. ShowLL usually is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. ShowLL is more low-level. Does not throw exception when fails, and does not add a delay; Show adds a small delay when the window is of other thread.
Calls API ShowWindow with SW_SHOWNA or SW_HIDE. Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsEnabled
member.summary: Gets the enabled state. Returns true if the window is enabled. Returns false if is disabled or is a child of disabled parent. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports . Calls API IsWindowEnabled.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Enable(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables or disables the window. Calls API EnableWindow.
member.param: Enable or disable.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsCloakedGetState
member.summary: Gets the cloaked state. Returns 0 if not cloaked or if failed. Else returns flags: 1 cloaked by its application, 2 cloaked by Windows, 4 cloaked because its owner window is cloaked. On Windows 7 returns 0 because there is no "cloaked window" feature.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsCloaked
member.summary: Returns true if the window is cloaked. Returns false if not cloaked or if failed. On Windows 7 returns false because there is no "cloaked window" feature. Windows 10 uses window cloaking mostly to hide windows on inactive desktops. Windows 8 - mostly to hide Metro app windows.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsMinimized

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsMaximized

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Lib._EnableActivate_SendKey(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sends a key (VK_0 up). It allows to activate now. Later this process can always activate easily (without key etc). It works even with higher IL windows. Don't know why is this behavior. Tested on all OS from XP to 10. Does not work if the foreground process has higher UAC IL.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Lib._EnableActivate_MinRes

member.name: F:Au.Wnd.Lib.ActivateFlags.NoThrowIfInvalid

member.name: F:Au.Wnd.Lib.ActivateFlags.NoGetWindow
member.summary: Don't call Get.Window (ie caller ensures it's a top-level window, not control).

member.name: F:Au.Wnd.Lib.ActivateFlags.IgnoreIfNoActivateStyleEtc
member.summary: Don't activate if has WS_EX_NOACTIVATE style or is toolwindow without caption, unless cloaked. Then just calls ZorderTop(), which in most cases does not work (inactive window).
