member.name: M:Au.Wnd.LibActivate(Au.Wnd.Lib.ActivateFlags)
member.summary: Activates this window (brings to the foreground). The same as , but has some options. Returns false if does not activate because of flag IgnoreIfNoActivateStyleEtc.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Activate
member.summary: Activates this window (brings to the foreground). Also unhides, restores minimized etc, to ensure that the window is ready to receive sent keys, mouse clicks ect.
member.remarks:
Activating a window usually also uncloaks it, for example switches to its virtual desktop on Windows 10. Fails (throws exception) if cannot activate this window, except:
If this is a control, activates its top-level parent window.
If this is , just deactivates the currently active window.
When the target application instead activates another window of the same thread.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ActivateLL
member.summary: Low-level version of . Just calls , API SetForegroundWindow and makes sure that it actually worked, but does not check whether it activated exactly this window. No exceptions, does not unhide, does not restore minimized, does not check is it a top-level window or control, etc. Returns false if fails.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Focus
member.summary: Sets the keyboard input focus to this control. Also activetes its top-level parent window (see ).
member.remarks: The control can belong to any process/thread. With controls of this thread you can use the more lightweight function . Works not with all windows. For example, does not work with Windows Store apps. Then use . Can instead focus a child control. For example, if this is a ComboBox, it will focus its child Edit control. Then does not throw exception. This can be control or top-level window. Top-level windows also can have focus.
member.exception: Invalid handle; disabled; failed to set focus; failed to activate parent window. Fails to set focus when the target process is admin or uiAccess and this process isn't (see UAC).

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.Focused
member.summary: Gets the control or window that has the keyboard input focus.
member.remarks: The control/window can belong to any process/thread. With controls/windows of this thread you can use the more lightweight function . Calls API GetGUIThreadInfo.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsFocused
member.summary: Returns true if this is the control or window that has the keyboard input focus.
member.remarks: This control/window can belong to any process/thread. With controls/windows of this thread you can use the more lightweight function . Calls .

member.name: T:Au.Wnd.ThisThread
member.summary: Functions that can be used only with windows/controls of this thread.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ThisThread.Focus(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Calls API SetFocus. It sets the keyboard input focus to the specified control or window, which must be of this thread. Returns false if fails. Supports .
member.remarks: Fails if the control/window belongs to another thread or is invalid or disabled. Can instead focus a child control. For example, if ComboBox, will focus its child Edit control. Then returns true.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.ThisThread.Focused

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.ThisThread.Active

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.MoveLL(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Au.Types.Native.SWP)
member.summary: Moves and resizes.
member.remarks:
See also . It is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. It throws exceptions, supports optional/reverse/fractional/workarea coordinates, restores if min/max, does not support SWP flags. This function is low-level, it just calls API SetWindowPos with flags NOZORDER|NOOWNERZORDER|NOACTIVATE|swpFlagsToAdd. It is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. Supports .
For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.MoveLL(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Moves.
member.remarks:
See also . It is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. It throws exceptions, supports optional/reverse/fractional/workarea coordinates, restores if min/max. This function is low-level, it just calls API SetWindowPos with flags NOSIZE|NOZORDER|NOOWNERZORDER|NOACTIVATE. It is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. Supports .
For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ResizeLL(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Resizes.
member.remarks: See also . It is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. It throws exceptions, supports optional/reverse/fractional/workarea coordinates, restores if min/max. This function is low-level, it just calls API SetWindowPos with flags NOMOVE|NOZORDER|NOOWNERZORDER|NOACTIVATE. It is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Move(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,System.Boolean,Au.Types.Screen_)
member.summary: Moves and/or resizes.
member.param: Left. If default(Coord), does not move in X axis.
Top. If default(Coord), does not move in Y axis.
Width. If default(Coord), does not change width.
Height. If default(Coord), does not change height.
x y width height are relative to the work area. Not used when this is a child window.
x y width height are relative to this screen or its work area. Default - primary. Not used when this is a child window.
member.remarks: Also restores the visible top-level window if it is minimized or maximized. For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client area coordinates. With windows of current thread usually it's better to use .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Move(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,System.Boolean,Au.Types.Screen_)
member.summary: Moves.
member.param: Left. If default(Coord), does not move in X axis.
Top. If default(Coord), does not move in Y axis.
x y are relative to the work area. Not used when this is a child window.
x y are relative to this screen or its work area. Default - primary. Not used when this is a child window.
member.remarks: Also restores the visible top-level window if it is minimized or maximized. For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates. With windows of current thread usually it's better to use .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Resize(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,System.Boolean,Au.Types.Screen_)
member.summary: Resizes.
member.param: Width. If default(Coord), does not change width.
Height. If default(Coord), does not change height.
For etc use width/height of the work area. Not used when this is a child window.
For Coord.Fraction etc use width/height of this screen. Default - primary. Not used when this is a child window.
member.remarks: Also restores the visible top-level window if it is minimized or maximized. With windows of current thread usually it's better to use .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.MoveInScreen(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Screen_,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves this window to coordinates x y in specified screen, and ensures that entire window is in screen.
member.param: X coordinate in the specified screen. If default(Coord) - screen center. You also can use etc.
Y coordinate in the specified screen. If default(Coord) - screen center. You also can use etc.
Move to this screen (see ). If default, uses screen of this window.
Use the work area, not whole screen. Default true.
If part of window is not in screen, move and/or resize it so that entire window would be in screen. Default true.
member.remarks: If the window is maximized, minimized or hidden, it will have the new position and size when restored, not immediately, except when moving maximized to another screen.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.EnsureInScreen(Au.Types.Screen_,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves this window if need, to ensure that entire window is in screen.
member.param: Move to this screen (see ). If default, uses screen of this window.
Use the work area, not whole screen. Default true.
member.remarks: If the window is maximized, minimized or hidden, it will have the new position and size when restored, not immediately.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.MoveToScreenCenter(Au.Types.Screen_)
member.summary: Moves this window to the center of the screen.
member.param: Move to this screen (see ). If default, uses screen of this window.
member.remarks: Calls ShowNotMinMax(true) and MoveInScreen(default, default, screen, true).

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.Screen
member.summary: Gets object of the screen that contains this window (the biggest part of it) or is nearest to it. If this window handle is default(Wnd) or invalid, gets the primary screen. Calls .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ZorderAbove(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Places this window before window w in the Z order. Also can make this window topmost or non-topmost, depending on where w is in the Z order. This window and w can be both top-level windows or both controls of same parent. May not work with top-level windows when it would move an inactive window above the active window. If w is default(Wnd), calls .
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ZorderBelow(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Places this window after window w in the Z order. Also can make this window topmost or non-topmost, depending on where w is in the Z order. This window and w can be both top-level windows or both controls of same parent. May not work with top-level windows when it would move an inactive window above the active window. If w is default(Wnd), calls .
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ZorderTop
member.summary: Places this window or control at the top of the Z order. If the window was topmost, it will be at the top of topmost windows, else at the top of non-topmost windows (after topmost windows). Does not activate. In most cases does not work with top-level inactive windows, although returns true; instead use .
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ZorderBottom
member.summary: Places this window or control at the bottom of the Z order. If the window was topmost, makes it and its owner window non-topmost.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ZorderTopmost
member.summary: Makes this window topmost (always on top of non-topmost windows in the Z order). Does not activate. If this window has an owner window, the owner does not become topmost. This cannot be a control.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ZorderNoTopmost(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Makes this window non-topmost. If this window has an owner window, makes the owner window non-topmost too. This cannot be a control.
member.param: Also place this window after the active nontopmost window in the Z order, unless the active window is its owner.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsTopmost
member.summary: Returns true if this is a topmost (always-on-top) window.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ZorderIsBefore(Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Returns true if this window is above window w in the Z order.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsOfThisProcess
member.summary: Returns true if this window belongs to the current process, false if to another process. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports . Calls API GetWindowThreadProcessId.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsUnicode
member.summary: Returns true if the window is a Unicode window, false if ANSI. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports . Calls API IsWindowUnicode.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.Is64Bit
member.summary: Returns true if the window is of a 64-bit process, false if of a 32-bit process. Also returns false if fails. Supports . If is true, calls API GetWindowThreadProcessId, OpenProcess and IsWow64Process. If you know that the window belongs to current process, instead use or IntPtr.Size==8. This function is much slower.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsHungGhost
member.summary: Returns true if the window is a ghost window that the system creates over a hung (not responding) window to allow the user to minimally interact with it.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsConsole

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.IsUacAccessDenied
member.summary: Returns true if UAC would not allow to automate the window. It happens when current process has lower UAC integrity level and is not uiAccess, unless UAC is turned off.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.ClassName
member.summary: Gets class name. Returns null if fails, eg if the window is closed. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ClassNameIs(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if the class name of this window matches className. Else returns false. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports .
member.param: Class name. Case-insensitive wildcard. Cannot be null.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ClassNameIs(System.String[])
member.summary: If the class name of this window matches one of strings in classNames, returns 1-based index of the string. Else returns 0. Also returns 0 if fails to get class name (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports .
member.param: Class names. Case-insensitive wildcard. The array and strings cannot be null.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.Name
member.summary: Gets name. Returns "" if no name. Returns null if fails, eg if the window is closed. Supports .
member.remarks: It is not the .NET Control.Name property. To get it you can use . Top-level window name usually its title bar text. Control name usually is its text that does not change, for example button or static (label) control text. Unlike , this function usually does not get variable text, for example Edit control editable text, ComboBox control selected item text, status bar text. Calls (false, true).

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.ControlText
member.summary: Gets control text. Returns "" if no text. Returns null if fails, eg if the window is closed. Supports .
member.remarks: Unlike , this function prefers variable text, for example Edit control editable text, ComboBox control selected item text, status bar text. For controls that cannot have such text (eg button, static), it usually gets the same text as Name. For example button and static (label) controls. Much slower than Name. Fails if the window is hung. Calls (true, false).

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.GetText(System.Nullable{System.Boolean},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets window/control name or control text. Returns "" if it is empty. Returns null if fails, eg if the window is closed. Supports . This is a low-level function. You can instead use and .
member.param: false - use API function InternalGetWindowText. It is fast and usually does not get variable text. This is used by . true - use API message WM_GETTEXT. It is slow and prefers variable text. This is used by . Fails if the window is hung. null - try InternalGetWindowText. If it gets "", and this is a control, then try WM_GETTEXT.
Remove the invisible '&' characters that are used to underline keyboard shortcuts with the Alt key. Removes only if this is a control (has style Native.WS.CHILD). Calls .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd._GetTextFast(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets text. Returns "" if it is empty. Returns null if fails, eg if the control is destroyed or its thread is hung. Supports . Calls API InternalGetWindowText. If it fails, and getControlTextIfEmpty==true, and this is a control, calls _GetTextSlow, which uses WM_GETTEXT.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd._GetTextSlow
member.summary: Gets text. Returns "" if it is empty. Returns null if fails, eg if the control is destroyed or its thread is hung. Supports . Uses WM_GETTEXT.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.SetText(System.String)
member.summary: Sets window/control name or control text.
member.param: Text. Can be null, it is the same as "".
member.remarks: Uses API WM_SETTEXT. Top-level window name usually its title bar text. For variable-text controls (edit, combo box, status bar, ...) this usually is the text that would get. For other controls (button, static, ...) and top-level windows this usually is the text that would get.
member.exception: Failed, for example the window is closed.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.NameAcc
member.summary: Gets of the accessible object (role WINDOW) of this window or control. Returns "" if the object has no name or failed to get it. Returns null if invalid window handle.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.NameWinForms
member.summary: Gets Control.Name property of a .NET Windows Forms control. Returns null if it is not a Windows Forms control or if fails. Use this with controls of other processes. Don't use with your controls, when you have a Control object. This is slow when getting names of multiple controls in a window. Instead create a instance and call its method for each control.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.ProgramName
member.summary: Gets filename of process executable file, like "notepad.exe". Return null if fails. Calls and .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.ProgramFilePath
member.summary: Gets full path of process executable file. Return null if fails. Calls and .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.ProgramDescription
member.summary: Gets description of process executable file. Return null if fails. Calls and .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Close(System.Nullable{System.Boolean},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Closes the window. Returns true if successfuly closed or if it was already closed (the handle is 0 or invalid) or if ==true.
member.param: If true, does not wait until the window is closed. If false, waits about 1 s (depends on window type etc) until the window is destroyed or disabled. If null (default), waits (as if false) if returns false.

If false (default), uses API message WM_CLOSE. If true, uses API message WM_SYSCOMMAND SC_CLOSE, like when the user clicks the X button in the title bar. Most windows can be closed with any of these messages, but some respond properly only to one of them. For example, some applications on WM_CLOSE don't exit, although the main window is closed. Some applications don't respond to WM_SYSCOMMAND if it is posted soon after opening the window, for example Internet Explorer.
member.remarks: The window may refuse to be closed. For example, it may be hung, or hide itself instead, or display a "Save?" message box, or is a dialog without X button, or just need more time to close it. If the window is of this thread, just calls or (if ==true) and returns true.

example.code: //close all Notepad windows Wnd.FindAll("* Notepad", "Notepad").ForEach(t => t.Close());

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Child(System.String,System.String,Au.Types.WCFlags,System.Func{Au.Wnd,System.Boolean},System.Int32)
member.summary: Finds a child control and returns its handle as Wnd. Returns default(Wnd) if not found. See also: , .
member.param:
Control name. String format: wildcard expression. null means 'can be any'. "" means 'must not have name'.
By default the function gets control names with . Can start with these prefix strings:
"***text " - use . It is slower and can be less reliable (because can get editable text), especially if className not used. It does not remove the invisible '&' characters that are used to underline keyboard shortcuts with the Alt key.
"***accName " - use . Useful when the control itself does not have a name but an adjacent Static text control is used as its name. Examples - Edit controls in dialogs. Slower.
"***wfName " - use .NET Windows Forms Control Name property. To get it this function uses . It is slower and can fail because of UAC.
"***id " (like "***id 15") - use control id. To get it this function uses . The id value cannot be wildcard expression. See also .
Control class name. String format: wildcard expression. null means 'can be any'. Cannot be "".
Callback function. Called for each matching control. It can evaluate more properties of the control and return true when they match. Example: also: t => t.IsEnabled
0-based index of matching control. For example, if 1, the function skips the first matching control and returns the second.
member.exception: This variable is invalid (window not found, closed, etc).
starts with "***", but the prefix is invalid. is "". To match any, use null. Invalid wildcard expression ("**options " or regular expression).
member.remarks: To create code for this function, use dialog "Find window or control". It is form Au.Tools.Form_Wnd in Au.Tools.dll.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.HasChild(System.String,System.String,Au.Types.WCFlags,System.Func{Au.Wnd,System.Boolean},System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns true if this window contains the specified control. Calls .
Using this function many times with same parameters is inefficient. Instead create new and call or . See example.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.HasChild(Au.Wnd.ChildFinder)
member.summary: Returns true if this window contains the specified control. Calls .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.HasAcc(Au.Acc.Finder)

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ChildById(System.Int32,Au.Types.WCFlags)
member.summary: Finds a child control by its id and returns its handle as Wnd. Returns default(Wnd) if not found. See also: , .
member.param: Control id.
This function supports flags DirectChild and HiddenToo. If both are set, it is much faster because uses API GetDlgItem. Else uses API EnumChildWindows, like .
member.remarks:
To create code for this function, use dialog "Find window or control". It is form Au.Tools.Form_Wnd in Au.Tools.dll.
Not all controls have a useful id. If control id is not unique or is different in each window instance, this function is not useful.
member.exception: This variable is invalid (window not found, closed, etc).

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ChildAll(System.String,System.String,Au.Types.WCFlags,System.Func{Au.Wnd,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Finds all matching child controls. Returns List containing 0 or more control handles as Wnd. Everything except the return type is the same as with .
member.remarks: In the returned list, hidden controls (when using WCFlags.HiddenToo) are always after visible controls.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ChildFast(System.String,System.String,Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Finds a direct child control and returns its handle as Wnd. Returns default(Wnd) if not found. See also: , . Calls API FindWindowEx. Faster than , which uses API EnumChildWindows. Can be used only when you know full name and/or class name. Finds hidden controls too.
member.param: Name. Use null to match any. "" matches "" (no name). Full, case-insensitive. Wildcard etc not supported. Must include the invisible '&' characters that are used to underline keyboard shortcuts with the Alt key.
Class name. Use null to match any. Cannot be "". Full, case-insensitive. Wildcard etc not supported.
If used, starts searching from the next control in the Z order.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: T:Au.Wnd.GetWnd
member.summary: Static functions of this class are used to get special windows (used like Wnd w = Wnd.GetWnd.Top;) and all windows. Instances of this class are used to get related windows and controls, like Wnd w2 = w1.Get.FirstChild; (here w1 is a Wnd variable).

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.Children(System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets child controls, including all descendants. Returns array containing 0 or more control handles as Wnd.
member.param: Need only direct children, not grandchildren.
Need only visible controls.
Place all array elements of hidden controls at the end of the array.
member.exception: This variable is invalid (window not found, closed, etc).
member.remarks: Calls API EnumChildWindows.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.AllWindows(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets top-level windows. Returns array containing window handles as Wnd.
member.param: Need only visible windows.
Place all array elements of hidden windows at the end of the array, even if the hidden windows are before some visible windows in the Z order.
member.remarks: Calls API EnumWindows. The list can be bigger than you expect, because there are many invisible windows, tooltips, etc. See also . By default array elements are sorted to match the Z order. On Windows 8 and later gets only desktop windows, not Windows Store app Metro-style windows (on Windows 10 only few such windows exist), unless this process has UAC integrity level uiAccess; to get such windows you can use .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.ThreadWindows(System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets top-level windows of a thread. Returns array containing 0 or more window handles as Wnd.
member.param: Unmanaged thread id. See , . If 0, throws exception. If other invalid value (ended thread?), returns empty list. Supports .
Need only visible windows.
Place all array elements of hidden windows at the end of the array, even if the hidden windows are before some visible windows in the Z order.
member.remarks: Calls API EnumThreadWindows.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.Owner
member.summary: Gets the owner window of this top-level window. Returns default(Wnd) if this window isn't owned or if fails.
member.remarks: A window that has an owner window is always on top of it. Controls don't have an owner window. Supports . This function is the same as , which also allows to change owner.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.Window
member.summary: Gets the top-level parent window of this control. If this is a top-level window, returns this. Returns default(Wnd) if fails.
member.remarks: Supports . This function is the same as .

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.DirectParent
member.summary: Gets the direct parent window or control of this control. Returns default(Wnd) if this is a top-level window or if fails.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.DirectParentOrOwner
member.summary: Gets the direct parent window or control of this control, or the owner window of this top-level window. Returns default(Wnd) if this is an unowned top-level window or if fails.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.LastActiveOwnedOrThis(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the most recently active window in the chain of windows owned by this window, or this window itself if there are no such windows. Returns default(Wnd) if fails.
member.param: Can return an owner (or owner's owner and so on) of this window too.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.RootOwnerOrThis(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the bottom-most owner window in the chain of owner windows of this window. If this window is not owned, returns this window. Returns default(Wnd) if fails.
member.param: If this is a child window, use its top-level parent window instead.
member.remarks: Supports .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.OwnersAndThis(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets all owner windows of this window, including this window or its top-level parent. Returns array that starts with this window or its top-level parent (if control).
member.param: Skip invisible windows.
member.remarks: This window can be top-level window or control. If control, its top-level parent window will be the first in the array. This function for example can be used to temporarily hide a tool window and its owners when capturing something from the screen.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.Top
member.summary: Gets the very first top-level window in the Z order.
member.remarks: Probably it is a topmost window. Calls API GetTopWindow(default(Wnd)).

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.Root
member.summary: Calls API GetDesktopWindow. It gets the virtual parent window of all top-level windows.

remarks.note: It is not the desktop window (see ) that displays icons and wallpaper.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.Shell
member.summary: Calls API GetShellWindow. It gets a window of the shell process (usually process "explorer", class name "Progman").
member.remarks: It can be the window that contains desktop icons (see ) or other window of the same thread.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.Desktop
member.summary: Gets the desktop window that displays desktop icons and wallpaper in its child control .
member.remarks: The "Show Desktop" command (Win+D) activates this window. It is not API GetDesktopWindow (see ) This function is not very reliable. May stop working on a new Windows version or don't work with a custom shell.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.DesktopControl
member.summary: Gets the control of "SysListView32" class that contains desktop icons and wallpaper. It is a child of .

remarks.note: This function is not very reliable. May stop working on a new Windows version or don't work with a custom shell.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.IsMainWindow(Au.Wnd,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns true if window w is considered a main window, ie probably is in the Windows taskbar. Returns false if it is invisible, cloaked, owned, toolwindow, menu, etc.
member.param: On Windows 10 include (return true for) windows on all virtual desktops. On Windows 8 include Windows Store apps (only if this process has UAC integrity level uiAccess).
Return false if w is minimized.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.MainWindows(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets main windows, ie those that probably are in the Windows taskbar. Returns array containing 0 or more Wnd.
member.param: On Windows 10 include windows on all virtual desktops. On Windows 8 include Windows Store apps (only if this process has UAC integrity level uiAccess).
member.remarks: Uses . Does not match the order of buttons in the Windows taskbar.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.GetWnd.NextMain(Au.Wnd,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets next window in the Z order, skipping invisible and other windows that probably are not in the Windows taskbar. Returns default(Wnd) if there are no such windows.
member.param: Start from this window. If default(Wnd), starts from the top of the Z order.
On Windows 10 include windows on all virtual desktops. On Windows 8 include Windows Store apps (only if this process has UAC integrity level uiAccess).
Skip minimized windows.
If w is not default(Wnd) and there are no matching windows after it, retry from the top of the Z order. Then can return w.
member.remarks: Uses . This function is quite slow. Does not match the order of buttons in the Windows taskbar.

member.summary: Like , but has only button, check box and radio button functions - Click, Check etc.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.WButton.Click(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sends a "click" message to this button control. Does not use the mouse.
member.param: Use . If false (default), posts BM_CLICK message.
member.remarks: Works not with all button controls. Sometimes does not work if the window is inactive. Check boxes and radio buttons also are buttons. This function can click them.

example.code: Wnd.Find("Options").Child("Cancel").AsButton.Click();

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.WButton.Check(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Checks or unchecks this check box. Does not use the mouse. Calls with state 0 or 1.
member.param: Checks if true, unchecks if false.
member.remarks: Works not with all button controls. Sometimes does not work if the window is inactive. If this is a radio button, does not uncheck other radio buttons in its group.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.WButton.SetCheckState(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sets checkbox state. Does not use the mouse.
member.param: 0 unchecked, 1 checked, 2 indeterminate.
Use . If false (default), posts BM_SETCHECK message and also BN_CLICKED notification to the parent window; if that is not possible, instead uses BM_CLICK message.
member.remarks: Does nothing if the check box already has the specified check state (if can get it). Works not with all button controls. Sometimes does not work if the window is inactive. If this is a radio button, does not uncheck other radio buttons in its group.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.WButton.IsChecked(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets check state of this check box or radio button. Calls and returns true if it returns 1.

member.summary: Gets check state of this check box or radio button. Returns 0 if unchecked, 1 if checked, 2 if indeterminate. Also returns 0 if this is not a button or if failed to get state.
member.param: Use . If false (default) and this button has a standard checkbox style, uses API BM_GETCHECK.

member.name: P:Au.Wnd.AsButton
member.summary: Casts this to .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ButtonClick(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Finds a child button by id and sends a "click" message. Does not use the mouse. Calls .
member.param: Control id of the button. This function calls to find the button.
Use . If false (default), posts BM_CLICK message.

example.code: Wnd.Find("Options").ButtonClick(2);

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ButtonClick(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Finds a child button by name and sends a "click" message. Does not use the mouse. Calls .
member.param: Button name. This function calls to find the button.
Button class name to pass to .
Use . If false (default), posts BM_CLICK message.

example.code: Wnd.Find("Options").ButtonClick("Cancel");

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.MenuClick(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Posts a "menu item clicked" notification (WM_COMMAND) as if that menu item was clicked. Does not use the mouse.
member.param: Menu item id. Must be in range 1 to 0xffff.
The menu item is in the title bar's context menu, not in the menu bar. Posts WM_SYSCOMMAND instead.
member.remarks: Works only with standard (classic) menus. The drop-down menu window class name must be "#32768". Works with menu items in window menu bar, system menu and some context menus. Does not use the menu itself. Just posts WM_COMMAND or WM_SYSCOMMAND message. Even if a menu item with this id does not exist. This variable is the window that contains the menu bar or system menu. Or the drop-down menu window (class "#32768") that contains the menu item.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.FromXY(Au.Types.POINT,Au.Types.WXYFlags)
member.summary: Gets visible top-level window or control from point.
member.param: Coordinates relative to the primary screen. Tip: When need coordinates relative to another screen or/and the work area, use or tuple (x, y, workArea) etc. Example: var a = Wnd.FromXY((x, y, true));. Also when need etc.
member.remarks: Alternatively can be used API WindowFromPoint, ChildWindowFromPointEx or RealChildWindowFromPoint, but all they have various limitations and are not very useful in automation scripts. This function gets non-transparent controls that are behind (in the Z order) transparent controls (group button, tab control etc); supports more control types than RealChildWindowFromPoint. Also does not skip disabled controls. All this is not true with flag Raw. This function is not very fast. Fastest when used flag NeedWindow. Flag Raw also makes it faster.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.FromMouse(Au.Types.WXYFlags)
member.summary: Gets visible top-level window or control from mouse cursor position. More info: .

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.ChildFromXY(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets child control from point. Returns default(Wnd) if the point is not in a child control or not in the client area of this window.
member.param: X coordinate in the client area of this window. Can be etc.
Y coordinate in the client area of this window. Can be Coord.Reverse etc.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.Find(System.String,System.String,Au.Types.WFEtc,Au.Types.WFFlags,System.Func{Au.Wnd,System.Boolean},System.Object)
member.summary: Finds a top-level window and returns its handle as Wnd. Returns default(Wnd) if not found. See examples.
member.param: Window name. Usually it is the title bar text. String format: wildcard expression. null means 'can be any'. "" means 'must not have name'.
Window class name. String format: wildcard expression. null means 'can be any'. Cannot be "".
Program file name, like "notepad.exe". String format: wildcard expression. null means 'can be any'. Cannot be "". Cannot be path. Or (process id), (thread id), (owner window). See , , , , .

Callback function. Called for each matching window. It can evaluate more properties of the window and return true when they match. Example: also: t => !t.IsPopupWindow.
Called after evaluating all other parameters except .

Text, image or other object in the client area of the window. Depends on type: string - an accessible object that must be in the window. Format: "'role' name" or "name". See . - arguments for . Defines an accessible object that must be in the window. - arguments for . Defines a child control that must be in the window. or - image that must be visible in the window. To find it, this function calls with flag . See also .
This parameter is evaluated after .
member.remarks:
To create code for this function, use dialog "Find window or control". It is form Au.Tools.Form_Wnd in Au.Tools.dll.
If there are multiple matching windows, gets the first in the Z order matching window, preferring visible windows. On Windows 8 and later finds only desktop windows, not Windows Store app Metro-style windows (on Windows 10 only few such windows exist), unless this process has uiAccess; to find such windows you can use . To find message-only windows use instead.
member.exception: is "". To match any, use null. is "" or 0. To match any, use null. Invalid wildcard expression ("**options " or regular expression).

member.remarks: The list is sorted to match the Z order, however hidden windows (when using ) are always after visible windows.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.FindFast(System.String,System.String,Au.Wnd)
member.summary: Finds a top-level window and returns its handle as Wnd. Returns default(Wnd) if not found. See also: , .
member.param: Name. Use null to match any. Full, case-insensitive. Wildcard etc not supported.
Class name. Use null to match any. Cannot be "". Full, case-insensitive. Wildcard etc not supported.
If used, starts searching from the next window in the Z order.
member.remarks: Calls API FindWindowEx. Faster than , which uses API EnumWindows. Can be used only full name and/or class name. Finds hidden windows too. To find message-only windows use instead. Supports . It is not recommended to use this function in a loop to enumerate windows. It would be unreliable because window positions in the Z order can be changed while enumerating. Also then it would be slower than Find and FindAll.

member.name: M:Au.Wnd.FindOrRun(System.String,System.String,Au.Types.WFEtc,Au.Types.WFFlags,System.Func{Au.Wnd,System.Boolean},System.Object,System.Action,System.Double,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Finds a top-level window (). If found, activates (optionally), else calls callback function and waits for the window. The callback should open the window, for example call . Returns window handle as Wnd. Returns default(Wnd) if not found (if is negative; else exception).
member.param: Callback function. See example.
How long to wait for the window after calling the callback function. Seconds. Default 60. See .
Finally the window must be active. Default: true.
member.exception: time has expired. Not thrown if <= 0.

example.code: Wnd w = Wnd.FindOrRun("* Notepad", run: () => Shell.Run("notepad.exe")); Print(w);

member.remarks: Calls . Does not process Windows messages and other events, therefore should not be used in threads with windows, timers, hooks, events or COM, unless is small. Supports APC. If the computer goes to sleep or hibernate during that time, the real time is the specified time + the sleep/hibernate time.

member.name: M:Au.Time.SleepDoEvents(System.Int32)
member.summary: Waits milliseconds. While waiting, retrieves and dispatches Windows messages and other events.
member.param: Time to wait, milliseconds. Or .
member.remarks: Unlike , this function retrieves and dispatches Windows messages, calls .NET event handlers, hook procedures, timer functions, COM/RPC, etc. Supports APC. This function can be used in threads with windows. However usually there are better ways, for example timer, other thread, async/await/Task. In some places this function does not work as expected, for example in Form/Control mouse event handlers .NET blocks other mouse events. Be careful, this function is as dangerous as . Calls API MsgWaitForMultipleObjectsEx and .

member.name: M:Au.Time.LibSleepDoEvents(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: SleepDoEvents + noSetPrecision.

member.name: M:Au.Time.DoEvents
member.summary: Retrieves and dispatches events and Windows messages from the message queue of this thread.
member.remarks: Similar to , but more lightweight. Uses API functions PeekMessage, TranslateMessage and DispatchMessage. Be careful, this function is as dangerous as Application.DoEvents.

member.name: T:Au.Time.LibSleepPrecision
member.summary: Temporarily changes the time resolution/precision of Thread.Sleep and some other functions.
member.remarks: Uses API timeBeginPeriod, which requests a time resolution for various system timers and wait functions. Actually it is the system thread scheduling timer period. Normal resolution on Windows 7-10 is 15.625 ms. It means that, for example, Thread.Sleep(1); sleeps not 1 but 1-15 ms. If you set resolution 1, it sleeps 1-2 ms. The new resolution is revoked (timeEndPeriod) when disposing the LibSleepPrecision variable or when this process ends. See example. See also . The resolution is applied to all threads and processes. Other applications can change it too. For example, often web browsers temporarily set resolution 1 ms when opening a web page. The system uses the smallest period (best resolution) that currently is set by any application. You cannot make it bigger than current value. It is not recommended to keep small period (high resolution) for a long time. It can be bad for power saving. Don't need this for Time.SleepX and functions that use them (Mouse.Click etc). They call when the sleep time is 1-99 ms. This does not change the minimal period of and System.Windows.Forms.Timer.

member.name: M:Au.Time.LibSleepPrecision.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls API timeBeginPeriod.
member.param: New system timer period, milliseconds. Should be 1. Other values may stuck and later cannot be made smaller due to bugs in OS or some applications; this bug would impact many functions of this library.

member.name: M:Au.Time.LibSleepPrecision.Dispose
member.summary: Calls API timeEndPeriod.

member.name: P:Au.Time.LibSleepPrecision.Current
member.summary: Gets current actual system time resolution (period). The return value usually is between 0.5 and 15.625 milliseconds. Returns 0 if fails.

member.name: M:Au.Time.LibSleepPrecision.TempSet1(System.Int32)
member.summary: Temporarily sets the system wait precision to 1 ms. It will be revoked after the specified time or when this appdomain ends. If already set, just updates the revoking time.
member.param: Revoke after this time, milliseconds.

member.name: M:Au.Time.LibSleepPrecision.LibTempSet1(System.Int32)

member.param: milliseconds of the caller 'sleep' function.

For periodic timers it is optional; the timer stops when the thread ends. This function must be called in the same thread as Start.

member.name: T:Au.WaitFor
member.summary: Contains functions to wait for a user-defined condition or variable.
member.remarks:
Specialized 'wait for' functions are in other classes, for example .
All 'wait for' functions have a secondsTimeout parameter. It is the maximal time to wait, seconds. If it is 0, waits infinitely. If >0, after that time interval throws . If <0, then stops waiting and returns default value of that type (false, etc).
While waiting, most functions by default don't dispatch Windows messages, events, hooks, timers, COM/RPC, etc. For example, if used in a Form/Control event handler, the form would stop responding. Use another thread, for example async/await/Task, like in the example. Or option Opt.WaitFor.DoEvents.

member.name: T:Au.WaitFor.Loop
member.summary: Can be used to easily implement 'wait for' functions with a timeout.
member.remarks: See examples. The code works like most 'wait for' functions of this library: on timeout throws exception, unless secondsTimeout is negative. Similar code is used by most 'wait for' functions of this library. See also ; usually it's easier; internally it uses similar code too.

member.name: P:Au.WaitFor.Loop.Period
member.summary: Current period ( sleep time), milliseconds. Initially it is Opt.WaitFor.Period, optionally multiplied by constructor's options.Period/10. Default 10 ms. Then each increments it until .

member.name: P:Au.WaitFor.Loop.MaxPeriod
member.summary: Maximal period ( sleep time), milliseconds. It is *50 (default 500).

member.name: P:Au.WaitFor.Loop.TimeRemaining
member.summary: Gets or sets the remaining time, milliseconds.

member.name: M:Au.WaitFor.Loop.#ctor(System.Double,Au.Types.OptWaitFor)
member.param: The maximal time to wait, seconds. If 0, waits infinitely. If >0, after that time interval throws . If <0, then returns false.
Options. If null, uses , else combines with it.

member.name: M:Au.WaitFor.Loop.Sleep
member.summary: Calls . If it returns true, returns false. Else sleeps for milliseconds, increments Period if it is less than , and returns true.

member.name: M:Au.WaitFor.Loop.IsTimeout
member.summary: If the secondsTimeout time is not expired, returns false. Else if secondsTimeout is negative, returns true. Else throws .

member.name: M:Au.WaitFor.Condition(System.Double,System.Func{System.Boolean},Au.Types.OptWaitFor)
member.summary: Waits for an user-defined condition.
member.param: The maximal time to wait, seconds. If 0, waits infinitely. If >0, after that time interval throws . If <0, after that time interval returns false.
Callback function (eg lambda). It is called repeatedly, until returns true. The calling period depends on .
Options. If null, uses , else combines with it.
member.returns: Returns true. On timeout returns false if is negative; else exception.
member.remarks: More info: .

member.name: M:Au.WaitFor.Handle(System.Double,Au.Types.WHFlags,System.IntPtr[])
member.summary: Waits for a kernel object (event, mutex, etc).
member.param: The maximal time to wait, seconds. If 0, waits infinitely. If >0, after that time interval throws . If <0, after that time interval returns 0.
One or more handles of kernel objects. Max 63.
member.returns: Returns 1-based index of the first signaled handle. Negative if abandoned mutex. On timeout returns 0 if is negative; else exception.
member.exception: Failed. For example a handle is invalid.
member.remarks: Uses API WaitForMultipleObjectsEx or MsgWaitForMultipleObjectsEx. Alertable. Does not use .

member.name: M:Au.WaitFor.LibWait(System.Int64,Au.Types.WHFlags,System.IntPtr[])
member.summary: Waits for a signaled kernel handle. Or just sleeps, if handles is null/empty. If flag DoEvents, dispatches received messages, hook notifications, etc. Calls API WaitForMultipleObjectsEx or MsgWaitForMultipleObjectsEx with QS_ALLINPUT. Alertable. When a handle becomes signaled, returns its 0-based index. If abandoned mutex, returns 0-based index + Api.WAIT_ABANDONED_0 (0x80). If timeMS>0, waits max timeMS and on timeout returns Api.WAIT_TIMEOUT. If failed, returns -1. Supports Native.GetError.

member.name: M:Au.WaitFor.LibWait(System.Int64,Au.Types.WHFlags,System.Object,Au.Types.LibWaitVariable,System.IntPtr[])
member.summary: The same as + can wait for message and variable. If msgCallback is not null, calls it when dispatching messages. If returns true, stops waiting and returns handles?.Length. If it is WaitMsgCallback, calls it before dispatching a posted message. If it is Func{bool}, calls it after dispatching one or more messages. If stopVar is not null, when it becomes true stops waiting and returns handles?.Length + 1.

member.name: M:Au.WaitFor.PostedMessage(System.Double,Au.Types.WaitMsgCallback)
member.summary: Waits for a posted message received by this thread.
member.param: Callback function that returns true to stop waiting. More info in Remarks.
member.remarks: While waiting, dispatches Windows messages etc, like . Before dispatching a posted message, calls the callback function. Stops waiting when it returns true. Does not dispatch the message if the function sets the message field = 0. Does not use .

member.name: M:Au.WaitFor.MessagesAndCondition(System.Double,System.Func{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Waits for a variable or other condition that is changed while processing messages or other events received by this thread.
member.param: Callback function that returns true to stop waiting. More info in Remarks.
member.remarks: While waiting, dispatches Windows messages etc, like . After dispatching one or more messages or other events (posted messages, messages sent by other threads, hooks, etc), calls the callback function. Stops waiting when it returns true. Similar to . Differences: 1. Always dispatches messages etc. 2. Does not call the callback function when there are no messages etc. Does not use .

member.name: M:Au.WaitFor.Variable(System.Double,System.Boolean@,Au.Types.OptWaitFor)
member.summary: Waits until a variable is set = true.
member.param: Stop waiting when this variable is set to true.
member.remarks: This function is useful when the variable can be changed by any thread. To wait for a variable changed while processing messages etc in this thread, it's better to use .

member.name: T:Au.Registry_
member.summary: Registry functions. Extends .

member.name: F:Au.Registry_.AuKey
member.summary: Default registry key, used when the key argument is null or @"\" or starts with @"\".

member.name: M:Au.Registry_.ParseKeyString(System.String@)
member.summary: Parses registry key string and returns hive as RegistryKey. If key starts with "HKEY_", removes hive name from it and returns that hive. For example, if key is @"HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Test", sets key=@"Software\Test" and returns Registry.LocalMachine. Else if key is null or @"\", sets key=Registry_.AuKey (@"Software\Au") and returns Registry.CurrentUser. Else if key starts with @"\", prepends Registry_.AuKey (@"Software\Au") and returns Registry.CurrentUser. Else just returns Registry.CurrentUser. Valid hive names: "HKEY_CURRENT_USER", "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE", "HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT", "HKEY_USERS", "HKEY_PERFORMANCE_DATA" or "HKEY_CURRENT_CONFIG".
member.param: Registry key. Can start with a hive name.
member.exception: 'key' starts with "HKEY_" but it is an invalid hive name.

member.name: M:Au.Registry_.Open(System.String,Microsoft.Win32.RegistryKey)
member.summary: Opens a key for read access. Returns null if the key does not exist. Uses .
member.param: Registry key. See
If not null, the 'key' argument is a subkey of this key or hive; if the 'key' argument is null or "", the function just returns parentKeyOrHive.

member.name: T:Au.Icons

member.returns: Returns icon handle, or default(IntPtr) if failed.
member.remarks: Later call or some HandleToX function that will destroy the icon.

member.name: M:Au.Icons.GetFileIcon(System.String,System.Int32,Au.Types.GIFlags)
member.summary: Gets file icon. Extracts icon directly from the file, or gets shell icon, depending on file type, icon index, flags etc.
member.returns: Returns null if failed.
member.param: Can be: Path of any file or folder. URL, like "http://..." or "mailto:a@b.c" or "file:///path". ITEMIDLIST like ":: HexEncodedITEMIDLIST". It can be of any file, folder, URL or virtual object like Control Panel. See . Shell object parsing name, like @"::{CLSID-1}\::{CLSID-2}" or "shell:AppsFolder\WinStoreAppId". File type like ".txt" or URL protocol like "http:". If it is a file containing multiple icons (eg exe, dll), can be specified icon index like "path,index" or native icon resource id like "path,-id". If not full path, the function will look in . See also . Supports environment variables (see ).
Icon width and height. Also can be enum , cast to int.

member.name: M:Au.Icons.GetFileIconImage(System.String,System.Int32,Au.Types.GIFlags)
member.remarks: Calls and converts to Bitmap.

member.returns: Returns icon handle, or default(IntPtr) if failed.

member.param: ITEMIDLIST pointer (PIDL).
Icon width and height. Also can be enum , cast to int.

member.name: M:Au.Icons.GetShellIconSize(Au.Types.IconSize)
member.summary: Gets the width and height of shell icons of standard sizes - small, large, extra large and jumbo. Jumbo is always 256. Others depend on text size (DPI) that can be changed in Control Panel. If text size is 100%, they usually are 16, 32, 48.

member.remarks: The icon is cached and protected from destroying, therefore don't need to destroy it, and not error to do it.

member.summary: Destroys native icon. Calls API DestroyIcon. Does nothing if iconHandle is default(IntPtr).

member.name: M:Au.Icons.HandleToIcon(System.IntPtr,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts unmanaged icon to Icon object. Returns null if hIcon is default(IntPtr).
member.param: Icon handle.

If true (default), the returned variable owns the unmanaged icon and destroys it when disposing. If false, the returned variable just uses the unmanaged icon and will not destroy; the caller later should destroy it with .

member.name: M:Au.Icons.HandleToImage(System.IntPtr,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts unmanaged icon to Bitmap object and destroys the unmanaged icon. Returns null if hIcon is default(IntPtr) or if fails to convert.
member.param: Icon handle.
If true (default), destroys the unmanaged icon.

member.name: M:Au.Icons.ParseIconLocation(System.String@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Parses icon location string. Returns true if it includes icon index or resource id.
member.param: Icon location. Can be "path,index" or "path,-id" or just path. Receives path.
Receives the number or 0.
member.remarks: Also supports path enclosed in double quotes like "\"path\",index", and spaces between comma and index like "path, index".

member.name: T:Au.Icons.ImageCache
member.summary: Gets icons of files etc as Bitmap. Uses 2-level cache - memory and file.

member.name: M:Au.Icons.ImageCache.Dispose
member.summary: Calls .

member.name: M:Au.Icons.ImageCache.SaveCacheFileNow
member.summary: Saves to the cache file now, if need. Don't need to call this explicitly. It is called by Dispose.

member.name: M:Au.Icons.ImageCache.ClearCache
member.summary: Clears the memory cache and deletes the cache file.

member.name: M:Au.Icons.ImageCache.GetImage(System.String,System.Boolean,Au.Types.GIFlags,System.Action{System.Drawing.Bitmap,System.Object},System.Object)
member.summary: Gets file icon as Bitmap. If it is in the memory cache, gets it from there. Else if it is in the file cache, gets it from there and adds to the memory cache. Else gets from file (uses and adds to the file cache and to the memory cache. Returns null if GetFileIconImage failed, eg file does not exist.
member.param: Any file or folder.

Get file type icon, depending on filename extension. Use this to avoid getting separate image object for each file of same type. This is ignored if filename extension is ".ico" or ".exe" or starts with ".exe," or ".dll,".
Flags for .

If not null, the cached image will be auto-updated when changed. Then will be called this function. It can update the image in UI. How it works: If this function finds cached image, it sets timer that after ~50 ms loads that icon/image from file again and compares with the cached image. If different, updates the cache. Does it once, not periodically. Use only in UI threads. Does not work if this thread does not retrieve/dispatch posted messages.
Something to pass to the callback function.

member.name: M:Au.Icons.ImageCache.GetImage(System.String,System.Func{System.Drawing.Bitmap},System.Action{System.Drawing.Bitmap,System.Object},System.Object,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets any icon or image using callback function. If it is in the memory cache, gets it from there. Else if it is in the file cache, gets it from there and adds to the memory cache. Else calls callback function, which should return image, and adds to the file cache and to the memory cache. Returns null if the callback function returns null.
member.param: Some unique name. It is used to identify this image in cache.
Called to get image. To convert icon handle to image, use .
Something to pass to the callback function.
If true (default), auto-updating can dispose unused image returned by .

member.name: M:Au.Perf.WakeCPU(System.Int32)
member.summary: Executes some code in loop for the specified amount of time. It should make CPU to run at full speed.
member.param: How long to speed up CPU, milliseconds. The minimal required time probably is about 100 ms, but depends on CPU.
member.remarks:
Code speed measurements often are misleading because of variable CPU speed. Most CPU don't run at full speed when not actively used.
You can make CPU speed constant in Control Panel -> Power Options -> ... Advanced -> Processor power management -> Minimum or maximum power state. There are programs that show current CPU speed. For example HWMonitor.
